div1.p: THE SCHOOL FOR ARROGANCE: A COMEDY.
THE SCHOOL for ARROGANCE: A COMEDY.
AS IT IS ACTED AT THE THEATRE ROYAL, COVENT GARDEN.
LONDON: PRINTED FOR G. G. J. AND J. ROBINSON, PATERNOSTER-ROW.

div1.head: PREFACE.
div1.p: THE Comedy of Le Glorieux, by M. Nericault Destouches, is the basis on which The School for Arrogance has been formed. From that I have taken the plan, several of the characters, and some of the scenes. Difference of arrangement, additional incidents, and what I deem to be essential changes of character, have all been introduced. The Count has but little resemblance to the original: Lucy and Mac Dermot none. Lady Peckham is a new character, and was first suggested by a friend; who, conceiving highly of the contrast which exists in life, between the pride of rank and the pride of riches, industriously sought to stimulate and rouse my imagination.

The subject of the piece is greatly interesting to morals, and highly worthy of the Theatre. Conscious of the great effects a perfect Comedy might have produced, I regret the imperfections of the present. Some good it will do: I regret that it cannot do more. Persuaded as I am of the moral
dignity of the stage, I cherish an enthusiastic wish to see the dramatic art surpass even all its former sublime efforts. Among the pleasures of the imagination, how frequently has its place been the first! Happy indeed should I be, could my success add the smallest impulse to the exertions of Genius: ineffably happy, would but this noble art once more boldly assert its rank; and render itself, not only the general love and delight of mankind, but the veneration of the wise.

It is with peculiar pleasure that I here acknowledge how much I am indebted to the conduct of Mr. Marshal; who, in consequence of the prejudices which it was imagined Mr. Harris laboured under, respecting me, acted, for a time, in my behalf, as the author of the piece. Though anxiously zealous for its success, he still continued impartially attentive to the interests of all parties; and sacrificed his own feelings to promote what he conceived to be a public good.

The tribute of justice is also due to Mr. Harris. This tribute I am happy to have an opportunity to pay. And, that I may
now be consistent, as I always have been, in my private and public language to Mr. Harris, I will here insert a copy of a letter which I wrote to him, when the comedy had been twice performed.

body.p:
I HAVE patiently waited the proper moment in which to write to you. That moment I hope is now come. I should be guilty of injustice, were I any longer to delay expressing my sense of the propriety with which you have acted, relatively to The School for Arrogance, after you had every reason to suppose it mine. Such conduct, Sir, is highly honourable; and is not only productive of the best effects, but must secure the best and most permanent applause. That you had conceived disadvantageous ideas of me I knew; though I have no doubt but I shall ultimately convince you that, even supposing me to be mistaken, my motives have been laudable ***** A single phrase, which relates entirely to myself, is here omitted.. With me you were
irritated; but you had the justice to forget the man, and promote the interests of the piece. This I hold it my duty to say to the world at large.

closer.salute: I am, Sir, Your obliged humble servant,

body.p: Mr. Harris kindly expressed the satisfaction which his own private feelings received, from this letter; nor can there be a doubt but that the propriety of his conduct, under such circumstances, will be as agreeable to himself, and as pleasing to the public, as it has been to me.

div1.head: PROLOGUE.
div1.byline: Spoken by Mr. BERNARD, in the character of a News-hawker.
div1.stage: After sounding and calling "Great news!" without, enter with a postman's horn, newspapers, cap, and livery.

lg.l: GREAT news! Great news! Extraordinary news!
Who'll buy, or give three half-pence to peruse?
(Sounds) Great news!—Pray did you call, Sirs? Here am I!
Of wants and wanted I've a large supply!
Of fire and murder, marriage, birth and death,
Here's more than I can utter in a breath!
Rapes, riots, hurricanes, routs, rogues, and faro!
Famine and flames in Turkey, and the plague at Cairo!
Here's tincture for the gums, which dentists make;
Whose teeth eat most when other people's ache.
Here are rich soups, hams, tongues, oils, sauce, sour krout:
And here's the grand specific for the gout!
Here's turtle newly landed; lamb house-fed:
And here a wife and five small children wanting bread.
Wholesale and retail British spirits here:
And here's the dying speech of poor small-beer!
Here are tall men, short women, and fat oxen:
And here are Sunday schools, and schools for boxing;
Here ruin'd rakes for helpmates advertise;
And only want 'em handsome, rich, and wise.
Great news! Here's money lent on bond, rare news!
By honest, tender-hearted, christian Jews!
Here are promotions, dividends, rewards;
A list of bankrupts, and of new-made lords.
Here the debates at length are, for the week:
And here the deaf and dumb are taught to speak.
Here Hazard, Goodluck, Shergold, and a band
Of gen'rous gentlemen, whose hearts expand
With honour, rectitude, and public spirit,
Equal in high desert, with equal merit,
Divide their tickets into shares, and quarters:
And here's a servant-maid found hanging in her garters!
Here! Here's the fifty thousand, sold at ev'ry shop!
And here's the Newgate calendar—and drop.
Rare news! Strange news! Extraordinary news!
Who would not give three-halfpence to peruse?
'Sblues! I forgot—Great news, again, I say!
To-night, at Covent Garden, a new play!
(In raptures) Oh! I'll be there! With Jack, our printer's devil!
We're judges, we! Know when to clap, or cavil!
We've heard our pressmen talk of, of—of Rome and Greece!
And have read Harry-Harry-Harry Stotle's master piece!
When we have paid our shilling, we're the town!
As wisely can find fault as those who pay their crown!
Nay we, like them, if it be bad or good,
Can talk, as fast as, as—as if we understood!
Oh! I'll be there; get the first row; and, with my staff,
I'll act the trunk-maker, thump, roar, encore, and laugh!
The prompter's boy has call'd our Jack aside;
And says the Play's to cure the world of pride!
That rich folks will no longer think they're born
To crush the weak, and laugh the poor to scorn!
The great 'twill teach that virtue, wit, and merit,
They may perchance possess, but can't inherit!
That learning, wisdom, genius, truth, and worth,
Are far more rich and rare than ribbands, rank, and birth!
Lord! Lord! Whoever heard of such a scheme?
Teach sense to wealth and pride! Your poets always dream!
Could he do this, there's no one will deny
That News! Strange news! would be the gen'ral cry.

div1.head: THE SCHOOL FOR ARROGANCE: A COMEDY.

div3.head: SCENE I. [The House of Sir PAUL PECKHAM.]
div3.stage: Enter LYDIA followed by MAC DERMOT.

sp.speaker: LYDIA.
sp.p: ONCE again, Mr. Mac Dermot, have done with this nonsense.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Arrah, and why so scoffish? Sure now a little bit of making love—

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Pshaw! Do me the favour to answer my questions. The Count, your master, is in love with Miss Lucy Peckham?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Faith, and you may say that.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Is he really well born?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Oh! As for that, honey, let him alone. The noblest blood of France, aye, and what is better, of Ireland too, trickles to his finger's ends. The Villars and the O'Connollies.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: And he wishes to marry into the family of the Peckhams?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: The divle a bit, my dear.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: He is viry willing to marry the young Lady, but not her family. His pride and his passion have had many a tough battle about that, d'ye see. Only think! A direct descindant of the former kings of Ireland, and collateral cousin to a prisent peer of France, to besmear and besmoulder his dignity by rubbing it against porter butts, vinegar casks, and beer barrels.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Miss Lucy is indeed a lovely girl, animated to excess, and sometimes apparently giddy and flighty: but she has an excellent understanding, and a noble heart; and these are superior to birth, which is indeed a thing of mere accident.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Faith, and that it is—I, a simple Irishman, as I am—why now, I would have been born a duke, had they been civil enough to have asked my consint.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: The Count fell in love with her at the convent, to which she was sent to improve her French.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: And where I think you first met with her?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p:
Yes—she saw me friendless, and conceived a generous and disinterested affection
for me.—He has followed her to England; has taken apartments in our neighbourhood, and lives in splendour—yet is not rich.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Um, um.—No—But then he is a Colonel in the Irish brigade; and, beside his pay, has sacrit supplies.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: From whom?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Faith, and I don't believe he knows that himself.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: That's strange!—His pride is excessive.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: To spake the truth, that now is his failing.—An if it was not for that, oh! he would be the jewel of a master!—He trates his infariors with contimpt, keeps his distance with his aquals, and values the rubbishing dust of his great grandfathers above diamonds!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: His character is in perfect contrast to that of his humble rival, Sir Samuel Sheepy; who, even when he addresses a footman, is all bows and affability; whose chief discourse is, Yes, if you please, and, No, thank you; and who, in the company of his mistress, stammers, blunders, and blushes, like a great boy.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: What is it you till me? He the rival of the Count my master! That old—

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: A bachelor, and only fifty; rich, of a good family, and a great favourite with Lady Peckham, by never having the courage to contradict her.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Why, there now! You talk of the Count's pride! Here is this city lady as proud as ten counts! Her own coach horses, ready harnessed, don't carry their heads higher! And then she is as insolent, and as vulgar, and—Hem!

div3.stage: Enter Lady PECKHAM and Sir SAMUEL SHEEPY, followed by two Footmen, in very smart morning jackets.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Here, fellers—go with these here cards [Footmen receive each a parcel of large cards, and are going] Oh! Tell that there butler to come to me—instantly.—And—Do you hear?—Vhen you comes back, get those dismal heads of yourn better powder'd; put on your noo liveries, and make yourselves a little like christians.—These creeters are no better nur brootes, Sir Samooel! They are all so monstrous low, and wulgar!—I have a party to-night; I hopes you vill make von?

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Certainly, my Lady.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Vhy, vhere is this butler?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: I am here, my Lady!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Is all the furniter rubb'd?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: All, my Lady!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: The m'ogany bright?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: As bees-wax can make it, my Lady!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Bow pots in the china jars?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Yes, my Lady!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: The picters on the hall stair-case scoured?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Clean, my Lady!—But, I— (hesitating)

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: You! You vhat?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: I am afraid their eyes and noses will soon disappear.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Psha!—Feller!—Are the noo prints come home?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Yes, my Lady!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: And the karakatoors hung up in the drawing room?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: All, my Lady!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: You shall come and see 'em, Sir Samooel!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Your Ladyship has exquisite taste.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Oh! Sir Samooel!—Vell, feller?

sp.speaker: "Butler.
sp.p: My Lady!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Vhat do you stand gaping at?

sp.speaker: "Butler.
sp.p: My Lady!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Vill you begone, feller?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Oh!—Yes, my Lady; (Aside) and thank you too! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: So, Miss! is Sir Paul come to town?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: I have not seen him, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Sir Paul generally sleeps at our country seat, at Hackney.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: A pleasant retreat, my Lady!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Wastly! A wery paradise!—Vhere is my daughter, Miss?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: I don't know, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: And vhy don't you know? Please to go and tell her Sir Samooel is here. [Exit Lydia.]—A young purson that my daughter has taken under her purtection.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Seems mild and modest, my Lady.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Not too much of that, Sir Samooel.—Who (Surveying Mac Dermot)—pray, who are you, young man?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: I!—Faith, my Lady, I—I am—mysilf: Mac Dermot.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: The Count's gintleman.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p:
Gentleman!—Gentleman, indeed!—Count's gentleman!—Ha!—A kind of mungrel Count, Sir Samooel; half French,
half Irish! As good a gentleman, I suppose, as his footman here! I believes you have seen him though?

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: I think I once had the honor to meet him here, my Lady.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: An honor, Sir Samooel, not of my seeking, I assure you! Aspires to the hand of Miss Loocy Peckham!—He!—An outlandish French foriner!—I hates 'em all! I looks upon none on 'em as no better nur savages! Vhat do they vant vith us? Vhy our money, to be sure! A parcel of beggars!—I vishes I vus Queen of England for von day only! I vould usher my orders to take and conquer 'em all, and transport 'em to the plantations, instead of negurs.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: I have heard, my Lady, that the Count was my rival.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: He your rival, Sir Samooel! He! A half bred, higglety-pigglety, Irish, French fortin hunter rival you indeed!— [Enter Lydia.]—Vell, Miss! Vhere is my daughter?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: In her own apartment, Madam, dressing.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: She'll be down presently, Sir Samooel—Gentleman indeed! The Count's Gentleman! Ha! Pride and Poverty!

div3.stage: [Exeunt Lady Peckham and Sir Samuel Sheepy.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: (Highly affronted) Pride!—By the holy footstool, but your Ladyship and Lucifer are a pair!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Here comes Sir Paul.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Then I will be after going.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: No, no; stay where you are.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Ah! My sweet dear Liddy! You are the angel I wished first to meet! Come to my— (Running up to her.)—Why how now, hussey? Why so shy?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Reserve your transports, Sir, for Lady Peckham.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Lady!—But who have we here?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Mr. Mac Dermot, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Oh! I remember—servant to the Count, my intended son-in-law.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: The viry same, Sir. [Bows.]

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: I hear an excellent character of your master. They tell me he is a fine, hearty, dauntless, swaggering fellow! If so, he is a man of family, and the very husband for my Lucy.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Faith, thin, and he is all that!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: As for this Sir Samuel Sheepy, he shall decamp—A water drinker! A bowing, scraping, simpering, ceremonious Sir! Never contradicts any body!—Dammee! An old bachelor! And he! He have the impudence to make love to my fine, young, spirited wench!—But he is my Lady's choice!—Is she within?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: I suppose we shall have a fine breeze on this subject! But, what! Am I not the monarch, the Grand Seignior of this house? Am I not absolute? Shall I not dispose of my daughter as I please? Do you hear, young man? Go, present my compliments to the Count, and tell him I mean to give him a call this morning.

div3.stage: [Lydia makes signs to Mac Dermot to stay.]

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: I am waiting for him here, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Waiting for him here, Sir! No, Sir! You cannot wait for him here, Sir!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: But, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: And, Sir! Why don't you go?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: The Count bid me, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: And I bid you, Sir—Pack! Begone! [Exit Mac Dermot.]—Now we're alone, my dear Lydia—Why, where are you going, hussey?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Didn't you hear my Lady call?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Call? No.—And if she did, let her call.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Surely, Sir, you would not have me offend her?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Offend! Let me see who dare be offended with you in this house! It is my will that you should be the Sultana!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Me, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: You, my Queen of Hearts! You! My house, my wealth, my servants, myself, all are yours!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: You talk unintelligibly, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Do I? Why then I'll speak plainer.—I am in love with you! You are a delicious creature, and I am determined to make your fortune!—I'll take you a house up in Mary-lebone; a neat snug box; hire you servants, keep you a carriage, buy you rings, clothes, and jewels, and come and sup with you every evening!—Do you understand me now?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Perfectly, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Well, and—hay!—Does not the plan tickle your fancy? Do not your veins tingle, your heart beat, your—hay? What say you?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p:
I really, Sir, don't know what to say—except that I cannot comply, unless a
Lady, whom I think it my duty to consult, should give her consent.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: What Lady? Who?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Lady Peckham, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: My wife!—Zounds! Are you mad? Tell my wife?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: I shall further ask the advice of your son and daughter, who will wonder at your charity, in taking a poor orphan like me under your protection; will be happy to see themselves ruined for my sake, and will profit by the example of so venerable a father.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Poh! Nonsense!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: A little farther off, if you please, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Nearer! Angel! Nearer!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: I'll raise the house, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Pshaw!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Help!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: My handkerchief! You sweet—

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Lydia! Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: How now, Sir!— [Aside to Lydia.] Hem!—Say it was a mouse—

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: What is the matter, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: What's that to you, Sir?—What do you want, Sir? Who sent for you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: I perceive you are not well, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: How were you taken?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Taken!— [Aside] Young scoundrel!—Take yourself away, Sir!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Impossible, Sir! You tremble! Your looks are disordered! Your eyes wild!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: [Aside] Here's a dog!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Be so obliging, Miss Lydia, as to run and inform Lady Peckham how ill my father is!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Why, you imp! [Stopping Lydia] Lydia! Stay where you are—You audacious!—Will you begone?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: That I certainly will not, Sir, while I see you in such a way!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Way, Sir!—Very well, Sir!—Very well!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: I'll reach you a chair, Sir—Pray sit down—Pray cool yourself.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Oh, that I were cooling you in a horsepond!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: You are growing old, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: You lie, Sir!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: You should be more careful of yourself—Shall I send for a physician?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: [Aside] Dammee, but I'll physic you! I'll—

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Your soup is ready, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Knew your worship's hour—Never made better in my life—Rich and high! Just to your worship's palate.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Why, fellow, don't you see I'm very ill?

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Ill, Sir Paul!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: That my eyes are wild, that I tremble, am old, and want a physician?

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Lord! Sir Paul! I have been your physician for these fifteen years!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p:
I tell you, I'm ill; and want cooling!
Ask that scoundrel else—I'm dying! So serve up your dose—

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Yes, your worship. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: [Muttering as he goes off] A sly, invidious—The demure dog has a mind to her himself—Yes, yes!—Oh! Dammee, pitiful Peter, but I'll fit you! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: You see, Sir!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: [Shrugging] I do.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: I must leave this family.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Leave! Why, charming Lydia, will you afflict me thus? Have I not declared my purpose?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Which cannot be accomplished. You promise marriage, but your father will never consent.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Then we will marry without his consent.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Oh, no! Do not hope it! When I marry, it shall be to render both my husband and myself respectable, and happy: not to embitter, not to dishonour both.

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: A person, who calls himself Mr. Dorimont, enquires for you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Heavens! Can it be? Shew him up instantly. [Exit Footman.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: You seem alarmed!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: No, no! Overjoyed!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Who is it?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: I scarcely can tell you. A gentleman who used to visit me in the convent.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Have you been long acquainted?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Little more than two years; during which he was my monitor, consoler, and guide

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: [Seeing him before he enters] His appearance—

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Is poor; but his heart is rich in benevolence. Pray leave us. [Exit Edmund.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: [Running to meet him] Ah! Sir—

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: I am happy to have found you once again.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: What, Sir, has brought you to England?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Business; part of which was to see you.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: You have been always generous and kind—Yet I am sorry you should see me thus.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Why? [Eagerly] What are you?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: An humble dependant—A lady's companion.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Alas! Why did you leave the convent without informing me?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: 'Twas unexpected.—You had forborne your visits; and I feared death, or some misfortune. At my mother's decease, the young lady with whom I live having an affection for me, and seeing me deserted, offered to take me with her to England, promising I should rather be her friend than her companion.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: And has she kept her word?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: On her part faithfully, tenderly!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: That is some consolation!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: But—

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: She has a mother, who does not fail to make inseriority feelingly understand itself.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: [With some emotion] Indeed!— [Collecting himself] But with whom were you in such earnest conversation when I entered?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: The brother of my young lady: a gentleman worthy your esteem.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: And worthy yours?—You blush!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Do you blame me for being just?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: No—He is rich, young, and handsome.—Do you often meet?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: We do.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: You are lovely, inexperienced, and unprotected!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Fear nothing—I shall not easily forget myself.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: [Earnestly] I hope not.—But what does he say?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: That he loves me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Is that all?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: No—He offers me secret marriage.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Secret marriage!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: I see the danger, and wish to shun it.—You may find me some place of refuge in France.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Can you so easily renounce all the flattering prospects love has raised?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Yes; and not only them, but love itself, when it is my duty.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Noble-minded girl!—Remain where you are—Nay, indulge your hopes; for know, your lover will be honoured by your hand.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Sir!—Honoured.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Honoured!—By birth you are greatly his superior.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p:
Can you be serious?—Oh, trifle not
with a too trembling heart!—Why did my mother conceal this secret from me?—Or, if true, why die and leave it unrevealed?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: There were reasons—She was not your mother.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Not!—Oh, sir! You have conjured up ten thousand busy thoughts!—Is my mother living?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: My father?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: He is.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Why has he so long forsaken me?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: That must be told hereafter. Be patient—wait the event.—You are acquainted, I think, with Count Conolly Villars?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: He visits here.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: I have business with him.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Ah, Sir! I fear you will meet a cool reception! Your humble appearance and his pride will but ill agree.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Fear not—My business is to lower his pride.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Sir! He may insult you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Humble though I myself am, I hope to teach him humility. To visit you, and to accomplish this, was the purport of my journey.—Adieu for the present—Think on what I have said; and, though by birth you are noble, remember, virtue alone is true nobility.

div3.stage: [Lydia rings. Exit Mr. Dorimont, and enter Lucy: her dress more characteristic of the girl than of the woman; and her manner full of life, but tempered by the most delicate sensibility.]

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Well, Lydia! Any news for me?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p:
Mr. Mac Dermot has been here, with
the Count's compliments; but in reality to see if Lady Peckham were at home. You know how much he wishes to avoid her.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Yes; and I don't wonder at it.—She has just been with me, ushering her orders, as she calls it.—"I desires, Miss, you vill receive Sir Samooel Sheepy as your intended spouse."—And so she has sent me here to be courted; and the inamorato is coming, as soon as he can take breath and courage!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: But why, my dear, do you indulge yourself in mocking your mamma?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Lydia, I must either laugh or cry; and, though I laugh, I assure you it is often with an aching heart.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: My dear girl!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I hope, however, you will own there is no great harm in laughing a little at this charming Adonis, this whimsical lover of mine!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Perhaps not.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: What can his reason be for making love to me?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: There's a question! Pray, my dear, do you never look in your glass?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Um—yes—But does he never look in his glass too?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Perhaps his sight begins to decay.—But are not you alarmed?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Do not you love the Count?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Um—Yes.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Well! And you know how violent and prejudiced Lady Peckham is!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p:
Perfectly! But I have Sir Paul on my side; and, as for Sir Samuel, he was dandled so
long in the nursery, and is still so much of the aukward, bashful boy, that he will never dare to put the question directly to me; and I am determined never to understand him till he does.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Here he comes.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Don't leave me.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: [Bowing with trepidation] Madam—Hem!—Madam—

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: [Curtsying and mimicking] Sir—Hem! Sir— [Aside to Lydia] Count his bows!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Madam, I—Hem!—I am afraid—I am troublesome.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Sir—Hem!—A gentleman of your merit—Hem!—

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: [Continues bowing through most of the scene] Oh, Madam!—I am afraid—Hem!—You are busy.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: [Curtsying to all his bows] Sir—Hem!—

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Do me the honour to bid me begone.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Surely, Sir, you would not have me guilty of rudeness?

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: [Aside] What a blunder!—Madam—Hem!—I ask ten thousand pardons!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Good manners require—Hem!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: That I should begone without bidding. [Going]

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: [Aside] I suppose I'm wrong again▪

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I didn't say so, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: [Turning quick] Didn't you, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: A person of your politeness, breeding, and accomplishments—Hem!—

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: [Aside] She's laughing at me.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Ought to be treated with all reverence. [Curtsying with ironic gravity.]

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: [Aside] Yes! She's making a fool of me!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Sir!—Were you pleased to speak, Sir?—Hem!—

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Hem!—Not a word, Madam!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: This will be a witty conversation.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I presume, Sir—Hem!—You have something to communicate.—

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Madam!—Hem!—Yes, Madam, I mean no, Madam—No—Nothing—Hem!—

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Nothing, Sir Samuel!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Hem!—Nothing—Nothing.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Then may I take the liberty, Sir, to enquire—Hem!—What the purport of your visit is?—Hem!—

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: The—the—the—Hem!—The—purport is—Hem!—I—I have really forgotten!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Oh, pray, Sir, take time to recollect yourself—Hem!—I am sure, Sir Samuel—Hem!—You have something to say to me—Hem!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Yes—No—no—nothing.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Fie! Sir Samuel! Nothing to say to a lady!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: No!—Hem!—I never had any thing to say to ladies in my life! That is—Yes—Yes—I own—I have something of the—the utmost—Hem!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: A thing which—lies at my heart!—Hem!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Mercy!—Sir Samuel!—Hem!—

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Which I—Hem!—Have long—But I will take some other opportunity. [Offering to go.]

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: By no means, Sir Samuel! You have quite alarmed me! I am impatient to hear! I am afraid you are troubled in mind—Hem!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Why—Hem!—Yes, Madam—Rather—Hem!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I declare, I thought so! I am very sorry! Perhaps you are afraid of death?

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Yet you are not so very old!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: But I would not have you terrify yourself too much—Hem!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I perceive I have guessed it.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Madam! Hem! No, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: No!—What then is this important secret?—Nay, pray tell me—Hem!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Hem! N—n—n—n not at present, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Nay, Sir Samuel!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Some other time, Madam—Hem!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: And can you be so cruel to me? Can you? I declare, I shall dream about you! Shall think I see you in your winding-sheet! Or some such frightful figure! And shall wake all in a tremble—Hem!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: A tremble indeed, Madam!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: And won't you tell me, Sir Samuel? Won't you?

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: N—n—n—n not at present, Madam—Hem!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Well, if you won't, Sir Samuel, I must leave you; for what you have said has absolutely given me the vapours!—Hem!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: I, Madam!—Have I given you the vapours?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Yes, you have, Sir Samuel; and shockingly too! You have put such gloomy ideas into my mind!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Bless me, Madam—Hem!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Your salts, Lydia!—Hem!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: I hope, Madam, you—you are not very ill!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Oh, I shall be better in another room—Hem!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: [Aside] Yes, yes; 'tis my company that has given her the vapours. [Aloud] Shall I— [Confusedly offering his arm.]

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: No, no—Stay where you are, Sir Samuel.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: [Aside] She wants to be rid of me!—Hem!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Only, remember, you are under a promise to tell me your secret—Hem!—If you don't, I shall certainly see your ghost! Remember—Hem! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Madam—I— [Not knowing whether to go or stay]— [To Lydia] Miss Lydia—Hem!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: If you would—hem! be so civil, I—

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Oh, Sir! I have the vapours as bad as Miss Lucy! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p:
Have you?—Hem! Bless me! Death! Winding-sheets! Ghosts!—Gloomy ideas indeed—Hem!—She was laughing at
me! I am sure she was! Hem! All my life long have I been laughed at by young coquettish girls! Yet I can't forsake 'em! Then the vapours! My old trick! I always give young ladies the vapours! I make 'em ill! They are always sick of me! Hem!—'Tis very strange that I can't learn to talk without having a word to say! A thing so common too! Why can't I give myself monkey airs, skip here and there, be self-sufficient, impertinent, and behave like a puppy, purposely to please the ladies? What! Is there no such thing to be found as a woman who can love a man for his modesty? This foreign count, now, my rival, is quite a different thing! He [Mimicking]—He walks with a straight back, and a cocked-up chin, and a strut, and a stride, and stares, and takes snuff, and—! Yes, yes! He's the man for the ladies! [Exit.

head.stage: an Apartment in the House of Sir PAUL PECKHAM.

sp.speaker: LYDIA.
sp.p: I CANNOT forget it—My father alive! And I of noble descent!—'Tis very strange!—Hope, doubt, and apprehension are all in arms! Imagination hurries me beyond all limits of probability!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Why do you thus seek solitude?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: To indulge thought.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Has your friend brought you bad news?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: What has he said?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Strange things!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Heavens!—What?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: You would think me a lunatic, were I to repeat them.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Lydia! I conjure you not to keep me on the rack!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: I was enjoined silence, but I feel my heart has no secrets for you—Yet, you will laugh.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Ungenerous Lydia!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Yes; you will think me mad.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Lydia, you are unjust.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Am I?—Well then, I am told—Would you believe it?—I am told that my family is illustrious!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Good heavens!—'Tis true! I feel it is true! Charming Lydia, [Kneeling] thus let love pay you that homage which the world, blind and malignant, denies.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Rise, Edmund. Birth can at best but confer imaginary dignity; there is no true grandeur but of mind.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Some one is coming!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Aye, aye! Get you gone.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: I am all transport!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Hush! Away!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: My angel! [Kisses her hand.]

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: A gentleman to you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: This sudden return, Sir, is kind.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: I have bethought me. The moment is critical, and what I have to communicate of importance. Are we secure?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: We are. This is my apartment. [Lydia goes and bolts the door.] Have you seen the Count, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: No. But I have written to him anonymously.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: And why anonymously?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: To rouse his feelings, wound his vanity, and excite his anger. His slumbering faculties must be awakened.—Is he kind to you?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: No. Yet I believe him to be generous, benevolent, and noble of heart; though his habitual haughtiness gives him the appearance of qualities the very reverse.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Worthy, kind girl!—You were born for the consolation of a too unfortunate father!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Again you remind me that I have a father. Why am I not allowed to see him? Why am I not suffered to fly into his arms?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: He dreads lest his wretched and pitiable condition should make you meet him with coldness.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Oh! How little does he know my heart! Yet speak; tell me, what monster was the cause of his misery?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: The monster Pride.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Pride!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Your mother's pride, which first squandered his wealth, and next endangered his life.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: How you alarm me!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: A despicable dispute for precedency was the occasion of a duel, in which your father killed his antagonist, whose enraged family, by suborning witnesses, caused him to be convicted of murder, obliged him to fly the kingdom, and with your mother wander under a borrowed name, a fugitive in distant countries.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Heavens!—But why leave me ignorant of my birth?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p:
That, being unfortunate, you might be humble: that you might not grieve after happiness which you seemed destined
not to enjoy. 'Twas the precaution of a fond father, desirous to alleviate, if not succour your distress.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Oh! How I burn to see him!—Is he not in danger? Is his life secure?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: He himself can scarcely say. His enemies have discovered him, are hot in pursuit, and fertile in stratagems and snares. They know that justice is now busied in his behalf; but justice is slow, and revenge is restless.—Their activity, I hear, is redoubled.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Guard, I conjure you, guard my father's safety! Let me fly to seek him! Conduct me to his feet!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: He wished you first to be informed of his true situation; lest, knowing him to be noble, you should expect to see him in all the pomp of affluence, instead of meeting a poor, dejected, forlorn old man.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: His fears are unjust; injurious to every feeling of filial affection and duty! The little I have I will freely partake with him. My clothes, the diamond which my supposed mother left me, whatever I possess shall instantly be sold for his relief: my life shall be devoted to soften his sorrows. Oh that I could prove myself worthy to be his daughter! Oh that I could pour out my soul to secure his felicity!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Forbear!—Let me breathe!—Affection cannot find utterance!—Oh! this melting heart!—My child!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: My Lydia!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Heavens!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: My child!—My daughter!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: [Falling at his feet] Can it be?—My father!—Oh ecstasy!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Rise, my child!—Suffer me to appease my melting heart!—Oh, delight of my eyes!—Why is not your brother like you?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: My brother! Who? Have I a brother?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: The Count is your brother.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: 'Tis too much!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: He is not worthy such a sister.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: The sister of the Count! I!—Ah! Nature, thy instincts are fabulous: for, were they not, his heart would have beaten as warmly toward me, as mine has done for him!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: I will make him blush at his arrogance. You shall witness his confusion; which shall be public, that it may be effectual.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Would you have me avoid explanation with him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Yes, for the present.—I mean to see him. Our meeting will be warm; but he shall feel the authority of a father.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: If you are a stranger to him, I fear lest—

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: No, no. He knows me, but knows not all his obligations to me.—I have secretly supplied him with money, and gained him promotion; which he has vainly attributed to his personal merits. But I must be gone. My burthened heart is eased! Once more, dear child of my affections, be prudent. I have much to apprehend; but, should the present moment prove benign, my future days will all be peace!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: [Alarmed] Who's there?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: [Without] 'Tis I!—Open the door!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: I am busy, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Pshaw! Open the door, Itell you!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Who is it?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Sir Paul.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: And does he take the liberty to come into your apartment?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, he will take any liberty he can.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Why don't you open the door?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: You are surrounded by danger and temptation!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Have no fears for me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Will you open the door, I say?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Let him come in. [Lydia unbolts the door.]

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: What is the reason, you dear little baggage, that you always shut yourself up so carefully?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: You are one of the reasons, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Pshaw! You need not be afraid of me!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: I'm not afraid of you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Why that's right. I'm come to talk matters over with you. My Lady's out—a wisiting. [Mimicking]—The coast is clear. I have secured my graceless dog of a son—I suspect—!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: What, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: But it won't do! Mind! Take the hint!—I've heard of an excellent house!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: You are running on as usual, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: With a convenient back door!—I'll bespeak you a carriage! Choose your own liveries! Keep as many footmen as you please! Indulge in every thing your heart can wish! Operas, balls, routs, masquerades! Rotten Row of a Sunday! Town house and country house! Bath, Bristol, or Buxton! Hot wells, or cold wells! Only—Hem!—Hay?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Sir, I must not hear such ribaldry.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Indeed but you must, my dear—How will you help it? You can't escape me now! I have you fast! No scapegrace scoundrel of a—! [Mr. Dorimont comes forward] And so—

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: [Sternly] And so, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Zounds! [Pause] And so! [Looking round] Locked up together! You were busy!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Well, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Oh, very, Sir! Perhaps you have a house yourself, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: With a convenient back door?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: So far from offering the lady such an insult, Sir, I am almost tempted to chastise that impotent effrontery which has been so daring.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Hem!—You are very civil, Sir! And, as a return for your compliment, I am ready to do myself the pleasure, Sir, to wait on you down stairs.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: I'll spare you the trouble, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Though this Lady's residence here will be but short, I would have you beware, Sir, how you shock her ears again, with a proposal so vile!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Your caution is kind, Sir!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: I am sorry it is necessary, Sir! What! The head of a house! The father of a family! Oh! Shame! He who, tottering on the brink of the grave, would gratify appetites which he no longer knows, by reducing the happy to misery and the innocent to guilt, deserves to sink into that contempt and infamy into which he would plunge unwary simplicity.

head.stage: the apartment of the Count, an elegant room, with chairs, sopha, glasses, pictures, &c.

div3.stage: MAC DERMOT and PICARD, with a letter in his hand, meeting.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: So, Mr. Picard; what have you got there?

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.p: Von lettre for Monsieur le Comte.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Well, give it me, and go about your business.

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.p: No! I not go about my bisaness! My bisaness is to speaka to you.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: To me!—And what is it you want?

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.p: Mon argent! My vage an my congé! My dismiss!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: How, man alive!

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.p: You are dee—dee factotum to dee Count. He suffare no somebody to speaka to him; so I am come speaka to you.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Arrah now, and are you crazy? Quit the sarvice of a Count! Your reason, man?

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.p:
My raison is you talka too mosh enough; he no talk at all! I follow him from France;
I yet live vid him by and by four month, he no speaka to me four vord!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.p: Vat den!—Je suis François, moi! I ave dee tongue for a dee speaka; I mus speaka; I vila speaka! He not so mosh do me dee faveur to scold a me! I ave leave dee best Madame in Paris for Monsieur le Comte—Quelle Femme! Her tongue vas nevare still! Nevare! She scold and she clack, clack, clack, clack, clack, from all day an all night! Oh! It vas delight to hear!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: And so you want to be scolded?

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.p: Oui—I love to be scold, I love to scold; to be fall out an to be fall in—C'est mon gout—Dee plaisir of my life! J'irai crever! If I no speak I burst!

sp.speaker: Mac. D.
sp.p: And is it you now, spalpeen, that would chatter in the prisence of the Count?

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.p: Shatter! Shatter! Ha! Vat you mean shatter?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Have not you roast beef and plum pudding?

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.p: Vat is roas beef, vat is plom boodin, gotam! if I no speaka? I ave a dee Master in France dat starva me, dat pay me no gage, dat leave a me tout en guenilles; all rag an tattare; yet I love him better as mosh! Pourquoi? [Affectionately] Helas! J'étois son cher ami! His dear fren! He talka to me, I talka to him! I laugh at his joke, he laugh aussi, an I am both togeder so happy as dee prince! But dee Count▪ Oh! He as proud!—Ha!—Comme ça. [Mimicking.]

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Poh! Now—My good fillow, have patience.

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.p: Patience! Moi!—I no patience—If I no speak I am enragé—I am French—I am Picard—Ven dee heart is full dee tongue mus run! I give you varn—Let my Masta speak, or I shall dismissa my Masta!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Here comes the Count! Stand back, man, and hould your tongue!

div3.stage: [Enter the Count, followed by two Footmen, in handsome liveries. Footmen place themselves in the back ground. Mac Dermot comes a little forward.]

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: The more I reflect on my own infatuation, the more I am astonished!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: My Lord—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Traversing the stage] A man of my birth! My rank! So to forget himself!—Still she is an angel!—But the family of a cit!—A brewer's daughter!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: My Lord—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Gives him a forbidding look] The world contains not a woman so lovely!—Yet the vulgar, haughty, disgusting airs of the mother! The insulting familiarity of the father! And the free, unceremonious tone of the whole family!—I am fascinated!"—Neither do they condescend to court my alliance! I must be the humble suitor: I must entreat, must supplicate permission to degrade my noble ancestors, who will abjure me, blushing through their winding sheets!—I must petition, and fawn, and acknowledge the high honour done▪—No! If I do!—Yet 'tis false! I shall! I feel I shall be thus abject.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: If—I might be so bould—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Well, Sir—

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: A letter for your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Oh!—What from the ambassador?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: No faith, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Ha! The Duchess▪

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: No, my Lord, nor the Duchess, neither.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Taking it] Who then, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Faith, my Lord, that is more than I can say—But perhaps the letter itsilf can tell you.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir!—Who brought it?

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.p: Un pauvre valet footaman, mee Lor—His shoe, his stocking, his habit, his chapeau, vas all patch an piece. And he vas—

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: [Aside, interrupting him] Bo!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Throwing down the letter, blowing his fingers, and dusting them with his white handkerchief] Foh!—Open it, and inform me of the contents.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.p: His visage, mee Lor—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: How now!

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.p: [In a pitiful tone] Mee Lor—

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: 'Sblood, man—! [Stopping his mouth, and pushing him back.]

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Makes signs to the footmen, who bring an arm-chair forward, and again submissively retire] She is ever uppermost! I cannot banish her my thoughts! Do you hear?—Dismiss those— [Waving his hand.]

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.—Hark you, spalpeens! [Waving his hand with the same air as the Count.] [Exeunt footmen.

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.p: [Advancing] Monsieur le Comte—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [After a stare] Again!

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.p: I ave von requéte to beg—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Pay that fellow his wages immediately!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: I tould you so! [Pushing him away] Hush! Silence!

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.p: Silence! I am no English! I hate silence! I—

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Poh! Bodtheration! Be asy!—I will try now to make your pace! [Pushes him off, and then returns to examining the letter.]

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Insolent menial!—Well, Sir? The contents?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Faith, my Lord, I am afraid the contints will not plase you!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: How so, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Why, as for the how so, my Lord, if your Lordship will but be plased to rade—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Didn't I order you to read?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: To be sure you did, my Lord; but I should take it as a viry particular grate favour, if that your Lordship would but be plased to rade for yoursilf.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Why, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Your Lordship's timper is a little warm; and—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Read!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Well—If I must I must!—The person who thinks proper, at present, to address you—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Interrupting] Sir!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: My Lord!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Be pleased to begin the letter, Sir!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Begin? Sarra the word of beginning is here—before or after—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: `The person'?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Mighty odd! [Throws himself in the arm-chair] Proceed, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: The person who thinks proper, at present, to address you, takes the liberty to inform you that your haughtiness, instead of being dignified, is ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Starting up] Sir!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Why now, I tould your Lordship!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Traversing the stage.] Go on!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: [With hesitating fear.] The little—merit—you have—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [With a look.] The little merit I have? The little?—The little?— [Mac Dermot holds up the letter.]—Go on!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: The little merit you have—cannot convince the world that your pride—is not—is not—is not—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Is not what? [Sternly.]

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: [Fearful] `Impertinent.'

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Striking Mac Dermot.] Rascal!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Viry well, my Lord!— [Throwing down the letter] I humbly thank your Lordship!—By Jasus! But I'll remimber the favour—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [More coolly] Read, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: To the divle I pitch me if I do!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Conscious of having done wrong] Read, Mac Dermot.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p:
No, my Lord!—Mac Dermot is a man!—An Englishman!—Or an Irishman, by Jasus, which is better still! And by the holy poker, if but that your Lordship was not a Lord
now!— [Pulling down his sleeves, and clenching his fist with great agony.]

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Carelessly letting his purse fall] Pick up that purse, Mac Dermot.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: 'Tis viry well!—Oh!—Well!—Well!—Well! [Lays the purse on the table.]

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: You may keep it—Mac Dermot.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: What!—I touch it!—No, my Lord!—Don't you think it!—I despise your guineas!—An Irishman is not to be paid for a blow!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [With increasing consciousness of error, and struggling with his feelings]—I—I have been hasty—

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Well, well!—'Tis viry well!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I am—I—I am sorry, Mac Dermot.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: [Softened] My Lord!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Emphatically] Very sorry—

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: My Lord!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Pray forget it! [Taking him by the hand] I cannot forgive myself.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: By the blessed Mary, then, but I can.—Your Lordship is a noble gentleman!—There is many an upstart Lord has the courage to strike, whin they know their poor starving depindants hands are chained to their sides, by writchedness and oppression: but few indeed have the courage to own the injury!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I will remember, Mac Dermot, that I am in your debt.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p:
Faith, and if you do, my Lord, your mimory will be better than mine!—I have lived with your Lordship some years; and, though not always a kind, you have always been a ginerous master. To be sure, I niver before
had the honour of a blow from your Lordship; but then I niver before had the satisfaction to be quite sure that, while you remimbered yoursilf to be a Lord, you had not forgotten poor Mac Dermot was a man.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Well, well! [Aside, and his pride returning] He thinks he has a licence now to prate.—There is no teaching servants; nay indeed there is no teaching any body a sense of propriety!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Did your Lordship spake? [Bowing kindly.]

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Give me that letter. And—take the money—It is yours.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Your Lordship will be plased for to pardon me there.—If you think proper, you may give me twice as much to-morrow.—But the divle a doit I'll touch for to-day!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Wait within call.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: [Going] I niver before knew he was all togedther such a jewel of a master! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: 'Tis this infernal letter that caused me to betray myself thus to my servant!—And who is this insolent, this rash adviser? May I perish if I do not punish the affront!—Here is no name!—A strange hand too!— [Reads] The friend who gives you this useful lesson has disguised his hand, and concealed his name—Anonymous coward!—His present intention being to awaken reflection, and make you blush at your own bloated vanity'—Intolerable! Or, if not, to prepare you for a visit from one who thinks it his duty to lower your arrogance; and who will undertake the disagreeable task this very day.—Will he? Will he?—Mac Dermot!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: [Entering] My Lord!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: If any stranger enquire for me, inform me instantly.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Good-morrow, Count.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Slightly bowing, and with vexation to Mac Dermot] Why, where are my fellows? No body to shew the gentleman up?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Oh! You are too ceremonious by half, Count!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [With quickness] A little ceremony, Sir, is the essence of good breeding.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Psha!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Psha, Sir!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Ceremony, like fringe hiding a beautiful face, makes you suspect grace itself of deformity.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Do you hear, Mac Dermot?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: My Lord!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: See that those rascals are more attentive!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Why, what is the matter with you, Count?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Muttering and traversing] Count! Count!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: You seem out of temper!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Strongly feeling his own impropriety] Oh dear! No—No—Upon my honour, no!—You totally mistake—I assure you, you mistake. I'm very glad to see you! I am indeed! [Taking him eagerly by the hand.]

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p:
I'm very glad you are. Though you have an odd mode of expressing your joy! But
you are one of the unaccountables! Cast off this formality—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Aside] Very fine! [Biting his fingers] Formality, Sir!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Give the heart its genuine flow!—Throw away constraint, and don't appear as if you were always on the tenter-hooks of imaginary insult!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I! [Aside] This is damn'd impertinent! [Struggling to be over-familiar] You entirely misconceive me! My character is frank and open! No man has less constraint! I even study to be, as it were, spontaneous!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! I perceive you do!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Really, Sir!— [Aside] Does he mean to insult me?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: I thought to have put you in a good humour.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I am in a good humour, Sir! I never was in a better humour, Sir! Never, Sir! 'Sdeath! A good humour, indeed!—Some little regard to propriety, and such manners as good breeding prescribes to gentlemen—

sp.speaker: Edm
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Well, well, Count, endeavour to forget the gentleman, and—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir! No, Sir: however you may think proper to act, that is a character I shall never forget.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Never, except at such moments as these, I grant, Count.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: By—!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Well gulped!—I had a sort of a message; but I find I must take some other opportunity, when you are not quite in so good a humour. [Going] I'll tell my sister what—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir!—Your sister!—My divine Lucy!—A message!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: So! The magic chord is touched!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Dear Sir, I—I, I, I,—I am afraid I am warm.—Your sister you said!—I doubt I—that is—

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Well, well, make no apologies.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Apologies! No, Sir!—I did'nt mean—That is—Yes—I—My Lucy! My Lucy! What message?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Nay, I cannot well say myself. You know the madcap.—She bade me tell you, if I happened [Significantly] to see you, that she wanted to give you a lecture.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Indeed! [Aside] I'm lectured by the whole family. [Aloud] On what subject?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Perhaps you'll take pet again!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I, Sir!—Take pet!—My sense of propriety, Sir— [Biting his lips.]

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Why, ay? Your sense of propriety, which, by the bye, my slippant sister calls your pride, [Count in great agitation] is always on the watch, to catch the moment when it becomes you to take offence.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: You—You are determined I shall not want opportunities!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: You mistake, Count—I have a friendship for you.—Why, what a forbidding stare is that now! Ay! A friendship for you.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir—I—I am not insensible of the—honour—

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Yes, you are.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
[With over-acted condescension] Sir, you are exceedingly mistaken! Very exceedingly! Indeed you are! As I am a man of honour,
there is no gentleman whom I should think it a higher—that is—Upon my soul—!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Is the Count at home, young man?

sp.speaker: Footman.
sp.p: [Without] Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: I hear my father! We have had a fracas; I must escape! If you will come and listen to my sister's lecture, so—Good-morrow! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: 'Tis insufferable! Never sure did man of my rank run the gauntlet thus! No respect! No distinction of persons! But with people of this class 'tis ever so—Hail fellow well met!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Ay! Hail fellow well met! Hay! You jolly dog! [Shaking him heartily by the hand.]

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Hem! Good—Good-morrow, Sir! [Aside] Here is another family lecturer!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Was not that young Mock-modesty that brushed by me on the stairs?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: It was your son, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Good morning, Sir! [Mimicking] said the scoundrel, when he was out of my reach.—Dammee! [With a kick] I would have shewn him the shortest way to the bottom!—Well—Hay! You have elegant apartments here!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [With contempt] Very indifferent, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p:
I shall remain in town for a fortnight, and am glad you live so near—We'll storm the wine-cellar!—I hear you are no flincher!—Hay! When shall we have a set-to!
Hay! When shall we have a rory tory? A catch, and a toast, and a gallon a man!—But—Hay!—What's the matter?—An't you well?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [With sudden excess of affability] Oh, yes, Sir Paul! Exceedingly well, Sir Paul! Never better, Sir Paul!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Why, that's right—I thought you had been struck dumb.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Oh! By no means, Sir Paul! I am very happy to see you! Extremely happy! Inexpressibly—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: I knew you would—What say you to my Lucy? Hay!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Say! That she—She is a phoenix! [In raptures.]

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Dammee, so she is! What is a phoenix?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I adore her!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: That's right!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: The day that makes her mine, will be the happiest of my life!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: So it will—For I'll make youas drunk as an emperor! Hollo, there!—Get your master's hat—Come, come; you shall dine with me. [Locking him by the arm.]

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Dammee, I'll make you drunk today!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Did you speak to me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: To you? Why, what the devil! Do you think I spoke to your footman? [Quitting his arm.]

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Again endeavouring to be affable] Oh, no, Sir Paul! No! I—Pardon me—I—I was absent.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Absent!—I smell a rat—Your dignity took miff!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: No, Sir Paul; by no means—No—I—That is—I will acknowledge, I am not very much accustomed to such familiarities.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Are you not? Then you soon must be.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Ay, Sir! A few lessons from me will cure you.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir—I—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: I am the man to make you throw off! I'll teach you to kick your stateliness down stairs, and toss your pride, as I do my wig, behind the fire.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Good breeding, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Good breeding, Sir, is a blockhead, Sir! None of your sormal Don Glums! None of your grand pas for me! A friend, good fellowship, and t'other bottle! That's my motto!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: People of my rank distinguish—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Damn distinctions!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: They make it a condition, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Indeed!—Look you, my dear Count, either unbridle, or you and I are two. You tell me you love my daughter—She is the finest girl in England; and I believe the slut has taken a fancy to you. The match pleases me, because it displeases my wife—And, except when you are riding your high horse, I like you, Count.—Dismount, and it's a match.—If not, turn the peg, and prance! I'm your humble!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Aside] I'll not endure it! Racks shall not make me bend to this!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Lucy is a wench after my own heart!—No piping, no pining, no sobbing for her! I have a fine fellow in my eye—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir! [Alarmed]

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: None of your Sir Ramrod Grumble-gizzards!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: By Heavens! I would cut the villain's throat who should dare impede my happiness!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Why ay! Dammee, now you talk!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: The loss of my Lucy would render me the most wretched of beings!

div3.stage: Enter MAC DERMOT with the hat.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: To be sure— [Taking him again by the arm] Come, come! [Claps the Count's hat on his head] Dinner is waiting! I smell the haunch! It perfumes the whole street! Come along! I hate the shackles of ceremony! A smoking table, and a replenished sideboard, soon put all men on a level! Your hungry and thirsty souls for me! He that enters my house, always deposits his grandeur, if he has any, at the door! [Sings]
"This brown jug, my dear Tom, which now foams with mild ale."

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Well said, old Toby! Oh! [Rubbing his hands.]

div3.stage: [Exeunt. The Count making disconcerted attempts to preserve his stateliness, wishing to be familiar, scarcely knowing how to behave, and Mac Dermot enjoying his embarrassment.

div3.head: SCENE I. The drawing-room of Sir Paul Peckham elegantly furnished, but hung all round with prints, chiefly caricatures.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: I SHALL never recover from my surprize!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Hush!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: The Count your brother?—My sister, my family, must be informed.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Not on your life, Edmund. So implacable are his enemies, that my father informs me an Exempt, bribed by them, has followed him to England.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Impotent malice! The laws will here protect him.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Oh! Who can say? The wicked cunning of such life-hunters is dreadful!—I insist therefore upon your promise.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: My Angel! Fear nothing! [Kissing her hand.]

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: [Placing herself beside Edmund] Turn about!—Now me. [Holding out her hand]

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Oh sister! I am the happiest of men!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: And you appear to be very busy too, with your happiness.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Did you but know!—

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Oh! I know a great deal more than you suspect—Not but you seem to be taking measures to inform the whole house.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Of what?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: [Placing herself between them] That you two are never easy apart.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Sister—I—I must insist that you speak of this Lady with—with every respect!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Brother!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Edmund!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: [Looking first at one and then at the other] Strange enough this!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Were I to tell you—

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: [Aside, and making signs] Very well!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Tell me what?—Why don't you tell me?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Pshaw! No no—Nothing—I—I don't know what I am saying.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Why surely you don't imagine your fondness for each other is any secret?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Sister! I don't understand—Are you narrow-minded enough to suppose this young lady unworthy the hand of—

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Of my brother?—No—To call my Lydia Sister [Taking her hand] is one of the things on earth I most fervently wish.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: My generous friend!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: My charming girl!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: But—then—

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p:
There are now no buts! It will be an honour—I say, sister, you—you don't know—In short I must very earnestly solicit you to treat
Miss Lydia with all possible delicacy—I—I—I cannot tell you more at present—But I once again request, I conjure, nay I—

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Hem!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Hem!—Humph!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: You—You understand me, sister. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Indeed I don't!—There now goes one of your Lord and Masters! Take care of him! He'll make an excellent grand Turk— [Humorously burlesquing] Treat Miss Lydia, I say, with all possible delicacy—And have I, Lydia, have I shewn a want of delicacy to my friend?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Oh, no! My heart throbs with an oppressive sense of your generous, your affectionate attention to me.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Oppressive?—Well! This is the proudest world!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Nay, I didn't mean—

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Oh! No matter!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Have you had any conversation with the Count?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: No—There has been no opportunity yet to-day—I am really afraid his pride is quite as absurd as that of my good Mamma!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: And your affection begins to cool.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Um—I—I can't say that—Heigho!—He has his faults.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: [Ardently] I hope he has his virtues too!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: So do I—But how to cure those faults?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: If incurable, 'twould break my heart!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Your ardor surprises me!—But, hush!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
[Bowing] I was afraid, Madam, love
would not have found so much as a moment to speak its anxieties—Nay even now— [Looking haughtily toward Lydia.]

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: [Pointedly, and almost in tears] Sir, I—I am sensible of my own unworthiness. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: That lady, Sir, is my friend.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Why are you surprised?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Madam!—No—no, not surprised—There is a maxim, indeed, which says—Friendship can only subsist between equals.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: But where is the inferiority?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: You are above the poor, the pitiful idea, that wealth confers any claims?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Perhaps it does not, Madam. But beauty, understanding, wit, in short, mind, confers ten thousand! And in these I never beheld your peer!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Very prettily spoken, indeed! And I am almost persuaded that you love me very dearly.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Madam, I adore you!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Yes, you are continually thinking of my good qualities.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Eternally, Madam! I think of nothing else!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: True—You never remember your own!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Were I totally insensible of my own, Madam, I should be unworthy of you.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p:
You admire me even in my representatives, my relations and friends! Affable to all, good-humoured to all, attentive to all, your politeness, ease, and urbanity extend to every
person for whom you think my heart is any way interested! Your passions are all subservient to love!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Yes, Madam; subservient is the very word! They are all subservient to love!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: You never recollect the dignity of your descent, nor accuse mine of meanness! You have too much understanding to plume your thoughts with turgid arrogance; or to presume on the imaginary merit of an accident, which none but ignorance, prejudice, and folly, are so besotted as to attribute to themselves!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Mankind have agreed, Madam, to honour the descendants of the wise and the brave.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: They have so—But you have too much native merit to arrogate to yourself the worth of others! You are no jay, decked in the peacock's feathers! You are not idiot enough to imagine that a skin of parchment, on which is emblazoned the arms and acts of one wise man, with a long list of succeeding fools, is any honour to you! Responsible to mankind for the use or the abuse of such talents as you feel yourself endowed with, you think only of how you may deserve greatly; and disdain to be that secondary thing, that insignificant cypher, which is worthless except from situation!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
The feelings of injured honour, Madam, perhaps may be too irritable. They shrink from insult, and spurn at contamination! Yet honour is the source of a thousand virtues! The parent of ten thousand glorious deeds! Honour is generous, sincere, and magnanimous! The protector of innocence, the assertor of right, the
avenger of wrong! Yes! Honour is the patron of arts, the promoter of science, the bulwark of government, the defender of kings, and the saviour of nations!—Indulge me then in cherishing a sentiment so noble!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Indulge?—Applaud, you mean! Honour with you never degenerates into ostentation! Is never presumptuous! Is no boaster! Is eager to earn, but scorns to extort pre-eminence! Your honour is not that abject inflated phantom which usurps contested claims, exacts submission which it does not merit, offends, irritates, and incites disgust, nay tarnishes even virtue itself! You do not, under the word Honour, seek a miserable cobweb covering for exorbitant pride!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Madam, accusation so pointed, so—

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Nay, now! Have not I been reading your panegyric?

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: My lady desires you will come to her immediately, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Very well [Exit Footman].—I am a thoughtless, slighty girl! What I say can have but little meaning—Else, indeed, I would have ventured to have given you a word of advice—But—'Tis no matter.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Madam, you have stung me to the soul! If I am indeed what you describe, 'twere time I should reform.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I must be gone.—I have, I own, been wildly picturing something to myself, which I greatly fear I could not love! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
And is it my likeness?—Surely it
cannot be!—Could not love?—Excruciating thought! [Exit after Lucy.

div3.stage: Enter EDMUND, in haste, and LYDIA from an inner chamber, meeting.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Where is the Count?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: This moment gone—

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: [Eagerly] Which way?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Through that door.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: [Running, stops at the door] Ah! 'Tis too late! The footman is telling him.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Why are you so much alarmed?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: The clouds are collected, and the storm is coming!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Lady Peckham has watched her opportunity: Sir Paul has dropt asleep in his armchair; she has ordered your sister to her apartment, and has sent to the Count to come and speak with her; that is, to come and be insulted, here in the drawing-room.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: What can be done?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: I know not—I dread her intolerable tongue.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Perhaps were you to retire, and, when they grow warm▪ to interrupt them at the proper moment, the presence of a third person might be some restraint on the workings of pride; of the violent ebullitions of which I am in great apprehension.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Had I but met the Count before he had received the message!—

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Here comes Lady Peckham. Begone!

div3.stage: Enter Lady PECKHAM, followed by a Footman▪

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: I have delivered your ladyship's message, and the Count is coming.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: [Swelling] Wery vell!—Go you about your business, feller— [Exit Footman.] Your company is not vanted, miss.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: So, Sir! They tells me, Sir, that you and my foolish husband are colloguing together, for to marry my daughter! Is this troo, Sir?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [With his usual polite haughtiness] If it were, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Do you know who Miss Loocy Peckham is, Sir?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Not very well, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Except that she is—your daughter.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: And do you know who I am, Sir?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I have been told, Madam—

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Told, Sir! Told! Vhat have you been told? Vhat have you been told, Sir?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: That your ladyship was an honest wax-chandler's daughter.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Yes, Sir! The debbidy of his vard, Sir! A common councilman, and city swordbearer! Had an aldermand's gownd von year, vus chosen sheriff the next, and died a lord mayor elect!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: With all his honours blooming on his brow.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p:
And do you know, Sir, that I designs Sir Samooel Sheepy, Sir, an English knight
and barrowknight, for the spouse of my daughter? A gentleman that is a gentleman! A purson of honour and purtensions, and not a papish Jesubite!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Of his honours and pretensions I am yet to be informed, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Vhat, Sir! Do you mean for to say, Sir, or to insinivate, Sir, that Sir Samooel Sheepy is not your betters?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: If Sir Samuel himself, Madam, had put such a question to me, I would have replied with my sword; or, more properly, with my cane.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Cane! Wery vell, Sir! I'll let Sir Samooel know that you threatens to cane him! I'll take care to report you! Cane quotha! He shall talk to you!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Let him, Madam!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Madam! Madam! At every vord—Pray, Sir, do you know that Sir Paul Peckham has had the honour to be knighted by the King's own hand?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I have heard as much, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Madam, indeed!—And for you for to think for to look up to my daughter!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Up, Madam!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Yes, Sir—Up, Sir!—Pray, Sir, vhat are your purtensions?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [With great agitation] Madam!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Who are you, Sir? Vhere do you come from? Who knows you? Vhat parish do you belong to?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Madam, I am of a family known to history, known to Europe, known to the whole universe!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Ah! I believes you are better known nur trusted!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: The names of Connolly and Villars, Madam, never before were so degraded as they have been in my person.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Oh! I makes no doubt but you are a purson that vould degurade any name!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Insult like what I have received from you, Madam, no man that breathes should utter, and escape death—But you are—

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Vhat, Sir? Vhat am I, Sir? Vhat am I, Sir?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: A woman.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: A voman, indeed! Sir, I vould have you to know, Sir, as how I am a lady! A lady, Sir, of his Majesty's own making! And moreover, Sir, don't you go for to flatter yourself that I shall bestow the hand and fortin of Miss Loocy Peckham upon any needy outlandish Count Somebody-nobody!
