My daughter, Sir, is for your betters!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Madam, though scurril— [Recollecting himself] I say, Madam, though such vul—such accusations are beneath all answer, yet I must tell you that, by marrying your daughter, if after this I should sink myself so low—I say by marrying your daughter, Madam, I should confer an honour on your family, as much superior to its expectations, as the splendour of the glorious sun is to the twinkling of the worthless glow-worm.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p:
Vhat!—Vhat!— [Enter EDMUND] Marry come up! An Irish French foriner! Not so good as von of our parish porpers! And you! You purtend to compare yourself to the united
houses of the Peckhams and the Pringles! Your family indeed! Yourn! Vhere's your settlement? Yourn! Vusn't my great uncle, Mr. Peter Pringle, the cheesemonger of Cateatonstreet, a major in the Train-Bands before you vus born, or thought of?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: [Aside] So, so! I'm too late! [Aloud] Let me entreat your Ladyship—

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Vhat! Hasn't I an ownd sister at this day married to Mr. Poladore Spragges, the tip-toppest hot-presser in all Crutched Friars! Isn't my maiden aunt, Miss Angelica Pringle, vorth thirty thousand pounds, in the South Sea funds, every day she rises! And doesn't I myself go to bed, and get up, the greatest lady in this here city? And for to purtend for to talk to me of his family! Hisn!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: [Very warmly] I must tell you, my Lady, you strangely forget yourself, and expose your family to ridicule.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: You must tell me, Sir! Vhy, Sir, how dare you have the temeracity for to come for to go for to dare for to tell me! Here's fine doings! Henpecked by my own chicken!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: The Count, Madam, is a man of the first distinction, in his native country!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Vhat country is that, Sir? Who ever heard of any country but England? A Count among beggars! How much is his Countship vorth?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
I had determined to be silent, Madam, but I find it is impossible! [With vehement volubility] And, I must inform you, my family is as ancient, as exalted, and as renowned, as you have proved yours to be—what I shall not
repeat! That I am the heir to more rich acres than I believe your Ladyship ever rode over! That my father's vassals are more numerous than your Ladyship's vaunted guineas! That the magnificence in which he has lived looked with contempt on the petty paltry strainings of a trader's pride!—And that in his hall are daily fed— [Stops short, and betrays a consciousness of inadvertent falsehood, but suddenly continues with increasing vehemence] Yes, Madam, are daily fed, now, at this moment, Madam, more faithful adherents, with their menials and followers, than all your boasted wealth could for a single year supply!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Are? At this moment, say you, Count?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir—I—I have said.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: I know you to be a man of honour, and that you cannot say what is not.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I—I—I have said, Sir. [Walking with great perturbation.]

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: You have said more in a minute nur you can prove in a year!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: [Warmly] Madam, I will pledge my life for the Count's veracity.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: You pledge! Vhat do you know about the matter? I'll pledge that he has been telling a pack of the most monstrous—

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Forbear, Madam! Such insult is too gross to be endured, almost, from an angry woman! Dear Count—

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Voman again! Wery fine! Wery pretty! Voman quotha! To be called a voman by my own witals!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Aside] What have I done!— [With agony] A lie!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p:
As for you, Sir, I doesn't believe
von vord you say! I knows the tricks of such sham shevaleers as you too vell!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Walking away from her] Torture!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: But I'll take care to have you prognosticated.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Aside] Damnation!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: I'll have you karakatoored in your troo colours! I'll have you painted in your father's hall; you and your vooden shoe shrug and snuffle scare-crows; your half dozen lank and lean shotten herring shadows; vith the light shining through 'em, like parchment at a vorkshop vinder; grinning hunger over a dish of soup-meegur, vith a second course of frogs; and a plate of hedge-berries and crab apples for the dessert! I'll depicter you! I'll not forget your wassals!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Aside] I can support it no longer. [Going.]

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: [Catches him by the hand] My dear Count—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir!—I am a dishonoured villain!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: There! There! He tells you himself he is a willin! His conscience flies in his face, and he owns it!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: [With great ardour and feeling] Madam! He is a noble-hearted gentleman! His agonizing mind deems it villainy to suffer insult so gross.—Sorry am I, Madam, to be obliged to tell you that, humble though your family is, the disgrace with which you have loaded it is indelible! With anguish of heart you force me to repeat, I blush while I listen to you! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p:
Vhy who ever heard the like of
this here now? Here's a prodigal son! Here's a regenerate reprobate! Here's a graceless Gogmagog! To purtend as how he's ashamed of me! Me! A purson of my carriage, connections, and breeding! I! Whose wery entrance, of a ball night, puts Haberdasher's-hall all in a combustion!

div3.stage: Re-enter the COUNT, deep in thought, and much agitated.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: [Seeing him] Marry my daughter, indeed!—Faugh! [Exit Lady Peckham.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Into what has my impetuous anger hurried me?—Guilty of falsehood!—I?—To recede is impossible!—What! Stand detected before this city madam! Whose tongue, itching with the very scrophula of pride, would iterate liar in my ear! No! Falsehood itself is not so foul!—Mac Dermot!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: My Lord!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Mac Dermot—I—You—You have heard of the state which formerly my father held; of his household grandeur, of the hinds and servants whom he daily fed, and the train by which he was attended!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: To be sure I have, my Lord.—Here, your dukes and your peers know nothing at all of style! Abroad, some hundreds starve, that one may ate! But, in England, they have learned the trick of aich man ating for himsilf!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Psha! Listen—The—The misfortunes that since have befallen us are little known in this country.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: To be sure they are not, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Nor—N—Hem!—Nor would I have them—D—D—D—a—Hem!—Do you understand me, Mac Dermot?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: My Lord!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I—I—I would not be exposed to the insolent taunts of upstart wealth.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Faith then, my Lord, you must not live in this city.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Nay, but—attend to me—I—I would—I would have them think—

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: [After waiting] What, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Traversing the stage, striking his forehead, and then returning] Mac Dermot—there are situations—I say, it may sometimes be wise, at least prudent—and—and—excusable—Have not you remarked, Mac Dermot, that Lydia— [Short pause.]

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Oh! To be sure I have remarked, my Lord, that she is a sweet crater; that Miss Liddy!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Nay, but—Her influence in the family—

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Oh yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Now—if—if—Suppose you were—to take—an opportunity—Is she proud?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Mild as mother's milk, my Lord!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: If she were persuaded—I say—Our family misfortunes—That is—No—No—The family magnificence—Do you comprehend me?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: My Lord!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Psha!—Damnation! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p:
[Stands some time amazed] Why, now, am I Mac Dermot, or am I not?—The Divle!—He would have me take an opportunity
with Miss Liddy!—Faith and I would very willingly do that—And persuade her—Oh! Honey, but she is not so asy to be persuaded! [Pauses] To be sure he must mane something! [Pauses again] Oh! Hona mon dioul! But I have it!—Ahoo! What a thickscull have I been, all this while!—He is a little bit ashamed to be thought poor, among this tribe of Balifarnians, who have nothing but their dirty guineas to boast of—And so he would have me persuade—Oh ho!—Let me alone. There she goes! I will be after—Bo! Flustration! There is that Mr. Edmund, now, close at her heels!—The young royster is always getting the sweet crater up in a corner!—Take an opportunity? Sarra the opportunity there is for me to take!

sp.speaker: MR. DORIMONT.
sp.p: PRAY, Sir, is the Count within?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: The Count, Sir! And pray why may you ask?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: I want to speak with him, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Spake! Oh! The Count is not so asy to be spoken with. Plase to deliver your message to me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Inform him I am come for an answer to my letter.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: [Alarmed] Letter, Sir!—What! The letter brought by a shabby footman?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Ay, ay—Has he read it?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Read it! Faith, and it has been very well read! But pray, Sir, now, are you the writer?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: I am.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: [With dread] Then take my advice! Make your escape!—'Tis very well for you my master is not at home!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: [Smiling] Why so?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Why so? Man alive! Have you a mind to be murdered?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Fear nothing. [Knocking heard.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: [With increasing terror] By the holy phial but there he is!—Why, will you begone now?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: No—I will not.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Marcy upon my soul!—For the Lord's sake, Sir!—Why, Sir, I tell you he'll have your blood! And won't you begone now?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Lord Jasus! What will I do? If he comes into this room, here will be murder!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Go—Tell him I am waiting for him.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Me tell him!—I warn you to begone! Remimber, I wash my hands of your blood.—Make off!—Make off, I tell you, while I go and keep him to his own apartment! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: [To a footman crossing] Hark you, young man! Tell the Count, your master, that the stranger, who wrote the anonymous letter to him, is here, waiting for an answer.

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Yes, Sir. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: The sears of the servant strongly speak the anger of the master.—But that was what I partly feared, and partly wished.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Enraged without.] Where is the rash, the audacious, [Enter COUNT] the insolent wretch, who— [Aside] My father!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: I scarcely could have expected so kind a welcome, Sir! 'Tis exemplary!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Passion, Sir, is sometimes guilty of improprieties—Pray pardon me!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I imagined— [Seeing Mac Dermot] How now, Sir! Begone!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Why so? Let him stay!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Begone, or!—

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Stay, I say!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: And do you hear—I am not at home.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: [Aside, and going] Oh Lord! Oh Lord! Here will be murder! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: What should that mean, Sir?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir!—There are reasons—I ought not to expose my father's safety.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Rather own, you ought not to blush at your father's poverty! Is this my reception? This the warm welcome of a duteous son?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: 'Tis so sudden—Yet my heart feels an affection—

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Which is stifled by your vanity! Your father is contemned, because he is unfortunate!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: No, Sir. I do not merit a reproach so cruel. Contemn my father! You know me not.—Tell me, which way can I prove my respect and love?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: By openly acknowledging me: not by concealment; not by disavowing me in the day of my distress!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Think, Sir, of your own safety!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: What danger is there with people of honour? Present me to the family of Sir Paul.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Impossible, Sir!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: [Sternly] Impossible!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Let me conjure you not to be too precipitate. You know not the vulgar pomp of new-made gentry; whose suffocating pride treats indigent merit, nay, birth itself, with the most imperious disdain!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p:
Talk not of their pride, but of
your own! You complain of others haughtiness? You! In whom the vice is so intolerable, that you willingly would disown your father!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir, you wrong me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: But, determined to be known for what I am, since you refuse, I'll introduce myself.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: For heaven's sake, Sir! I entreat! I supplicate! On my knees, I conjure you to forbear!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Yes; pride, kneeling, conjures a father in poverty to suffer himself to be disclaimed! Your mother's pride was my house's downfal: this she has bequeathed to you!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir— [Starts up at hearing]

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: [Without] I tell you, I know he is at home!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: [Without] Upon my soul, Sir Paul—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Zounds! Why I saw him from my own window!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Alarmed] Here is Sir Paul! You know not, Sir, how much is at stake! I have not time to tell you now; but let my intreaties—!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Oh! How humble are the proud! But remember, I consent only on condition that you restrain your arrogance. If, while I am present, any symptom— [Retiring back.]

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: 'Sblood! I knew you were at home! But to instruct servants how to lie, with the most cool, composed, and barefaced impudence, is one branch of modern education.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I am sorry, Sir Paul.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Pshaw! Damn apologies. I have good news for you.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: I do believe, (God forgive me!) that my wife is growing reasonable!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Does she consent?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Yes—To permit you to ask her pardon.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir! Ask pardon?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: [Advancing] Yes, Sir; ask pardon.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Hem!— [Aside] Zounds! Again!—Why, what the plague can he do here?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Your servant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Sir, your very humble.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Aside, and alarmed] What can this mean?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: You seem surprised, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Yes! You have a trick of taking people by surprise.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Aside] Does he know him?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: [Aside, and then to the Count] Odd enough!—Who is this queer old fellow?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Aside] All is safe!— [Aloud] Sir, the—the—gentleman [Aside] What shall I say? [To Sir Paul] A gentleman, Sir, who—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: A gentleman!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Yes—That is—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: What, some poor relation, I suppose?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Yes, Sir—A relation—The—the family estates have been under his management.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Oh! Your steward?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: No—Not absolutely my—my steward—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: What, your land-bailiff, then?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: No, Sir—No—That is—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Does not seem to have made his fortune by his office! A little weather-beaten.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: He is a man of the strictest probity, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Nay, his appearance is the pledge of his honesty!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: [Aside] I can perceive he is practising deceit! Oh vanity! But I will restrain my anger. The moment of open punishment is not yet come.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Crossing to his father] Let me request you, Sir, not to reveal yourself.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: [Drily] Well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Returning to Sir Paul] His oeconomy and good management are equal to his fidelity.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: [Aside] Confounded odd all this, though! [Aloud] Well, Count, I have exerted my whole authority with Lady Peckham; and her son Edmund, who has more influence over her than any body else, is your friend. So be wary, do your duty, and the day is your own.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: My duty, Sir!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Yes, Sir. Your duty, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: [Aside] A damned strange fellow! [Aloud] Is it not your duty, Count, to serve yourself?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: And would you contend about a word?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Very true, Sir!—You seem a—a plain spoken—a—Hem!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: [Significantly] Yes! I think it my duty to tell vice, and folly, the truth.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Hem!—You hear, Count?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: His punctilious pride is contemptible!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Half forgetting himself] Sir!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: And Sir!—I repeat: do your duty, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: [Aside] The most unaccountable! Hem!—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Aside] I am on the rack! He will betray himself.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: [To the Count] The old gentleman does not mince matters!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Aside to his Father] You will ruin me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Do as he requires, or I will feign no longer.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Lady Peckham is expecting you. Come, come; try whether you cannot put on a winning submissive air.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Aside] I shall burst!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Submissive, Sir!—Remember!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I shall not forget, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: You approve my advice, don't you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Entirely. The lesson you give him, Sir, is a useful and a necessary one. I know him!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Aside] Fiends!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: What, Sir—You—have lived long in the family?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Nay, don't be affronted!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [To Sir Paul] Let us begone, Sir! I am ready to attend you.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: [Aside] The bluntest, drollest—!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: We are losing time, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Well, well; in a moment. [To Mr. Dorimont] Pray, under favour, what may be the amount of the Count's rent roll?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Sir! His rent roll, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Ay, his rent roll—The nett produce of his estates?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Why that question to me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Coming between them] For heaven's sake, Sir Paul, let us go.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: 'Sblood! What a violent hurry you're in all of a sudden!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Endeavouring to force him away] Lady Peckham is waiting, Sir. I beg, I entreat—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: [Aside] The mystery thickens!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, has the Count—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Interrupting] For the love of mercy, Sir, answer no questions; hear none, ask none! I am frantic!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: [To the Count] Silence, Sir! [To Sir Paul] Has the Count ever talked of his estates?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Oh yes.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Aside] Damnation!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: And told you the amount?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: No—no—But, as you—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I must insist, Sir, on going. [To Sir Paul.]

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p:
I'm not prepared, Sir, just now to answer your question, of the rent roll. I have business, and must leave you; but I will
shortly give you the information you require. In the mean time, young gentleman, think on what has passed! Observe Sir Paul's advice, and act as becomes you. Put off your vanity—Be humble, and know yourself. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Aside fervently] Thank heaven he is gone!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Your steward is an odd one!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir—I—I tell you he is not my steward.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: What is he then?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir—I—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: I thought you taught every body to keep their distance; but he treats you with as little ceremony as— [Aside] as he did me.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; people do take very unaccountable liberties.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: But what brought him here?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir—He—Business, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Oh, the family estates.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: And pray, Sir, what do you know of him?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: I—Nothing.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: You appear to be acquainted.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Um—No, no.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: You had seen him before.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Hem! Yes, I had seen him. Come, let us be going.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: But permit me to ask.

sp.speaker: "Sir Paul.
sp.p: Pshaw!" Come, come—Lady Peckham is waiting.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
I must own, Sir Paul, I meet with many mortifications. Your daughter is an angel. But there are certain things to which a man
of my rank must not, cannot stoop. Do you, Sir Paul, come to an agreement with your lady, and I am ready.— [Calls] Mac Dermot!—I'll return in a moment. [Retires.]

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Now, if the demon of ambition did not possess me, I should never truckle to the self-sufficient airs of this man of rank! He has put a spell upon me!—I'll break with him this moment—Yet, if I do that, all is over. My authority is gone! Madam will be triumphant; and then farewel to submission!—Beside, the honour of the alliance! Nobility! Precedence! A family so famous! 'Sblood! Who knows but my grandson may be a Marshal of France? [To the Count, who returns] Come, come, Count; let us begone. You must make your peace with my Madam.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Solicitation, Sir Paul, does not become me; it is a thing I have not been accustomed to. Do you speak for me. Say all, say every thing you please. Your mediation will, I presume, be sufficient.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: [Quite angry] Damn me if this is not beyond all human patience! After all I have done in your behalf! What! Would you have me and my whole family approach your footstool, there present my daughter, and kneeling beg your highness to accept her? No, my haughty Count! Either my daughter is worth asking for, or not worth having. Carry your pomp to a better market; I'll stoop to it no longer. Your servant, Sir! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
[Following] Nay, Sir Paul—Must I endure this? Must I?—I! The descendant of an
ancient race! The rightful lord of athousand vassals! Ought I to cringe in supplicatory baseness, use servile dishonourable adulation, bend to sufflated wealth, act the parasite to new-fledged pride, and petition where I should command? No! Earth should hide me rather! But that love, imperious love hurries me forward, with impulse irresistible! What! Wait, and fawn on Madam, and mince, and simper, and act the skipjack, and chatter to her parrot, and be of her opinion, and fetch and carry, and praise her taste, and join her scandal, and laugh when she laughs, and kiss her monkey!—And to whom?—Oh! [Exit.

head.stage: SCENE changes to the House of SIR PAUL PECKHAM.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Oh, yes! Stabling for a hundred horses! Open house all the year about! Sarvants five and twinty to the score; all making work for one another!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Then the Count, your master, should be immensely rich.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Should be? To be sure he is. Don't I tell you—

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Yes; you tell me one thing at night, and another in the morning—You had forgotten the Colonel's pay!—And the secret supplies!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: [Aside] Faith, and so I had!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: And pray was this all your own invention?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Why, as to that—And is it me, now, that you would have to betray my master?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: What, then, he bid you spread this report?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Arrah now, did I say that?—Did I say that?—I tell you he bid me no such thing!—What, and did you think, now, you could get that out of me? By St. Patrick, but I would bite off my tongue, if it should dare to blunder out one word against so good a master!—

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: [Aside] Honest, affectionate fellow!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: [Aside] Oh! Blarney!—She wants to be too cunning for me, the sweet crater! And so, for fear of—Miss Liddy, your servant.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: I almost love him myself, for his love to his master.

div3.stage: Enter SIR PAUL, followed by EDMUND.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: I tell you, I have done with him. He is a pompous, insolent coxcomb! The Great Mogul himself is a fool to him!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: All men have their foibles, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Damn his foibles. I have enough to do with my own! And, do you hear, Sir? [Significantly] Don't let me be troubled with any of your foibles either! You understand me. [Looking at both] I'll not be trifled with. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: What has put him into so ill a humour?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: The cursed supercilious haughtiness of the Count. He has insulted Sir Samuel Sheepy, too!

sp.speaker: "Lydia.
sp.p: I am sorry for it; but that's a trifle.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p:
You are mistaken. Sir Samuel's resentment is very high; and, notwithstanding
the servility of his manner, is more to be apprehended than you imagine.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Surely you do not expect a challenge?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Nay, my love, I would not wish to terrify you.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: But you have terrified me!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Well, brother, have you succeeded with my mamma?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: I believe so—I can't tell—Where is the Count?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I hear him on the stairs.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Well, warn him to be careful.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: The old story! The Count's pride. If he should quarrel again with Lady Peckham, all will then be over!

sp.speaker: Lucy
sp.p: You have put me quite in a tremor!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: [Going] I will inform my mamma, Sir, that you are here; and she will be with you immediately.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: May I not, Madam, be indulged with one previous word?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; one, and but one. Instead of conciliating, I find your manners offend and disgust every one. Either cast away your hauteur, regain the affections and consent of my friends, and above all make your peace with Lady Peckham, or this shall be the last meeting of our lives! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p:
Are you aware, Sir, of your danger? Sir Samuel, Sir Paul, Lady Peckham, all affronted!
Nay your best friend, Edmund, has this moment left the room to avoid you! Oh! Think on that lovely lady! And if you have any affection for her, for yourself, or for your father—recall your reason, discard your folly, and act with a little common sense! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: This is strange!—My father?—She know my father?—And why am I schooled and tutored thus? What have I done? What is it they expect from me?—Do I indeed offend and disgust?—Which way? Has not love induced me to overlook all the high distinctions which honour holds sacred? Nay, am I not now come on the most abject of errands?—Yet, to lose her—! The last meeting of our lives!—They will absolutely drive me mad among 'em!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Madam [Bowing]—When I last had the honour—of a—an interview with your ladyship, I—I am afraid—I might possibly be inadvertently betrayed into—some warmth.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Vhy, Sir, seeing as how my son tells me you are a real nobleman, and not von of the rifraff fortin hunting fellers, if so be as you thinks fit to make proper pologies, vhy, Sir, I—I—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: To a lady, Madam, every apology may be made. Any concessions therefore—

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p:
Oh, Sir, as for that there, I vants nothing but vhat is right and downright. And I supposes, Sir, you are wery villin to own that an outlandish foriner must think himself highly
honoured, by a connexion with an English family of distinction. Because that I am sure you cannot deny. And that it vus a most perumptery purceedin in you, being as you are but a Frenchman, or of an Irish generation at best, to purtend to the hand and fortin of Miss Loocy Peckham, vithout my connivance.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: As I tells you, Sir, I am upright and downright. So do you, or do you not?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Madam—! I am ready to acknowledge that the charms of your daughter's mind, and person, are equal to any rank!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Her mind and purson, indeed! No, Sir! Her family and fortin!—And I believes, Sir, now you are come to your proper senses, you vill own too that no outlandish lord, vhatever, can uphold any comparagement vith the Peckham family and connexions!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [With great warmth and rapidity] Madam, though I am ready to offer every excuse which can reasonably be required, for any former inadvertency; yet, Madam, no consideration whatever shall lead me—I say, Madam, my own honour, a sense of what is due to my ancestors, myself, and to truth—that is, Madam—No! The world, racks, shall not force me to rank my family with yours.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p:
Vhy, Sir! Vhat is it that you are talking of? Rank my family vith yourn, indeed! Marry come up! No, to be sure! I say rank! I knows wery vell vhat is my doo: and that there, Sir, is the thing that I vould have you for to know! And I insist upon it, Sir, that you shall know it; and shall own that you
knows it; or, Sir, I rewoke every thing I have condescended to specify vith my son! So do you, Sir, or do you not?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Madam—What, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Do you depose, that outlandish foriners are all beggars, and slaves; and that von Englishman is vorth a hundred Frenchmen?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Madam—Whatever you please. [Bows.]

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Oh! Wery vell!—And do you purdict that this here city is the first city in the whole vorld?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I—I believe it is, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Oh! Wery vell!—And that the Moniment, and the Tower, and Lununbridge, are most magnanimous and superfluous buildings?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Madam—

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: I'll have no circumbendibus! Are they, or are they not?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Your ladyship is pleased to say so. [Bows.]

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: To be sure I does! Because I knows it to be troo! And that the wretches in forin parts are all fed upon bran; seeing as how there is no corn?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: As your ladyship thinks! [Bows.]

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: And that the whole country could not purwide von lord mayor's feast?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I—Certainly not, Madam: they have few turtle and no aldermen.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p:
Ah! A pretty country, indeed! No aldermen! And that it vould be the hite of
pursumption, in you, for to go for to set yourself up as my equal? Do you own that?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Passionately] No, Madam!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: No force, no temptation shall induce me so to dishonour my great progenitors!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Vhy, Sir!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: My swelling heart can hold no longer! Honour revolts at such baseness! Patience itself cannot brook a fallacy so glaring! No! Though destruction were to swallow me, I would assert my house's rights, and its superior claims!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Wery vell, Sir! Wastly vell, Sir! And I vould have you for to know, Sir, vhile my name is my Lady Peckham, I vill dissert my houses rights, and claims! That I despises all—! Ha, ha!—Ha! Wery fine, indeed! Am I to be sent here to be hectored, and huffed, and bluffed, and bullied, and bounced, and blustered, and brow-beat, and scoffed, and scouted, and—! Ha!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Recovering his temper and interceding] Madam—

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: I a brought my hogs to a fine market! But I'll let 'em know who's at home!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: My warmth, Madam—

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Your honour and glory, indeed! And for to purtend for to send for me here, to palaver me over as I supposed—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I am ready to own, Madam—

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p:
But I'll rid the house of you! I'll take good care you shall have no daughter of mine! You may post off to your father's hall, and there starve in state. Varm it with a blaze of dried leaves, and stop up the gaps in the
shattered vinders, and old groaning doors, vith clay; then send your shivering wassals, that stand jabbering behind your von armed vooden chair, to skin the sheep that died of hunger and the rot, to make you a varm vinter surtout!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Still interceding] Madam—

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: My daughter, indeed! I'll karakatoor you! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Flames and fury! [Following, is met by Sir Samuel Sheepy, who shuts the door after him, and will not suffer the Count to pass.] How now, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: [Bowing] Sir, your humble servant.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: What does this mean, Sir? Let me pass!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: A word or two first, if you please, Sir.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Let me pass! [Putting his hand to his sword.]

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: [Bowing, but resolutely guarding the door] Sir I must humbly entreat—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Damnation!—What is it you want with me, Sir? Who are you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: My name is Sheepy, Sir. [Bowing.]

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sheepy? [Aside] So, so, so! Hell and the devil! At such a moment as this!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: I am told, Sir, I have some obligations to you, which it becomes me to discharge.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Not quite so well, Sir, as I could wish. [Bowing.]

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Aside] Was ever man so tormented?

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: I am informed, Sir, that you have condescended to mention me, in my absence.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: And so, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: You did me an honour, Sir. [Bowing.]

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Either speak your business, and suffer me to pass, or I will nail you to the door!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Dear Sir, you are so warm! [Bowing]—I have been told you were so good as to threaten to cane me.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Ay, Sir? By whom!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: By Lady Peckham, Sir.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Indeed!—Well; suppose it.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: 'Twas kind of you!—Unluckily, I have not been much used to threatening messages, and am really afraid I shall not be very prompt at submission.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Oh, do not doubt yourself, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Humble though I am, I do not find that a swaggering look— [Bowing.]

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir! [With his hand to his sword.]

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Moderate your anger, kind Sir—I have a petition to you. [Putting on his white gloves.]

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Damn your sneer, Sir! Speak!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Bless me, Sir! You are so warm! It is only that you would kindly do me the favour either to cut my throat, or suffer me to cut yours. [Draws and flourishes.]

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [With his hand to his sword] Are you mad, Sir? Do you recollect where you are? In whose house?

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p:
Gadso! True, Sir! I should be sorry to be interrupted—Luckily, my carriage is at the door; and I know a snug room in a
neighbouring tavern, where this business may be effectually settled, as quietly, as coolly, and as privately as possible.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: 'Twere well for you, Sir, had you chosen another opportunity—But come!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Oh! Sir! I know my place—After you! [Bows.]

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Away, Sir! [Exeunt.

head.stage: SCENE changes to the COUNT's Apartment.

div3.stage: A considerable noise of hasty footsteps without, and voices at some distance calling—"Here! Here!—This way!—Up, up!—Follow!"

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: I am pursued, beset, and cannot escape!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Blood and thunder! Why what's all this? Oh! And is it you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Where is the Count?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Faith and that is more than I can tell. [Noise approaching—"Here, here, I tell you! This room!"] Why what the divle—!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: I am hunted! My liberty, perhaps my life, is in danger!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Why sure the Count would not—

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Here! Take, hide this packet from the eyes of my pursuers! Don't lose it; but, if you have any sense of worth and honesty, deliver it safe into the hands of Sir Paul Peckham!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Niver fear me, honey.

div3.stage: Enter an EXEMPT, and two BAILIFFS.

sp.speaker: Exempt.
sp.p: That's the man. Seize him!

sp.speaker: First Bail.
sp.p: Sir, you are our prisoner.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: On what authority, Sir?

sp.speaker: First Bail.
sp.p: Authority, Sir? The authority of law, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: For what crime?

sp.speaker: First Bail.
sp.p: As to crime, Sir, I can't tell; but for a trifling debt, of fifty thousand pounds.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: At whose suit?

sp.speaker: Exempt.
sp.p: At mine, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Yours? Vile wretch! Gentlemen▪ he is a spy: the creature of a foreign Court! I never had dealings with him in my life!

sp.speaker: First Bail.
sp.p: We know nothing of that, Sir. He has sworn to the debt.

sp.speaker: Exempt.
sp.p: No parleying; take him away.

sp.speaker: First Bail.
sp.p: Ay, ay. Come, Sir. [They all three forcibly drag him out.]

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: [Going and without] Help! Rescue! False Imprisonment!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Why what is all this now?—Poor ould gintleman!

div3.stage: [Noise without at a distance—"Rescue! Rescue! Help!"]

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Where is my shillalee?—Oh, by St. Peter and his crook, but I will be one among you, scoundrels! [Exit running.

div3.head: SCENE, The House of SIR PAUL PECKHAM.

sp.speaker: EDMUND.
sp.p: BE pacified: you are too much alarmed.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: If Sir Paul should have let them pass, what dreadful consequences may have followed! Where can he be?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: He is here!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Oh, Sir!—Where are they?—Has any thing happened?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Happened!—Dammee! I could not believe my own ears!—A silky Simon!—The Count was in a right humour—'Sblood! I had a great mind to have let him kill the old fool.

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Then they have not fought! Are they safe, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Yes, yes; they are safe enough—But do you know the amorous swain, his blood being heated, could only be pacified on condition that he might have another interview with Lucy!—I'm glad on't!—I'll go and give her her lesson.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, leave him to my sister, she needs no instructions.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: No?—Gad, I believe not! She's my own girl! But clear the coast; he is coming!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: I will go to Lady Peckham; and do you, Lydia, watch for the Count.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Ay, ay. He is suddenly grown humble; apologized to me, and promised to come and plead with my lady. But away.
sp.stage:
[Exeunt Edmund and Lydia, and
Enter SIR SAMUEL SHEEPY.
sp.p: Well, Sir Samuel, you are here!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Yes, Sir. [Aside] And I half wish I was any where else, already.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: And so you absolutely have the courage to attack my Lucy? Ha, ha, ha! Why you are quite a hero! You fear neither man nor woman!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: [Aside] I wish I didn't—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Nay, but don't begin to look so pitiful! She'll be here in a minute. Don't flinch! Stand to your guns! She'll not easily strike! Ha, ha, ha! Die hard, my old boy!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: What is the matter with me? I declare he has talked me into a tremble! Why should I be so terrified at a harmless woman? I can't help it! A pair of beautiful eyes are flaming swords, which no armour can resist!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: So, Sir Samuel!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Bless me!—My heart is in my mouth!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: You seem taken by surprise.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Madam—Hem!—No, Madam—Yes, Madam. [With his usual bows.]

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: My Papa informed me you were waiting, purposely to disclose this important secret.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Madam—Hem!—Yes, Madam—

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Do you know that I have had you in my mind I don't know how often, since I saw you?

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Hem!—Have you, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Yes, I have—'Tis a pity, nay indeed a shame, that so famous an English family as that of the Sheepy's should become extinct.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Hem!—There is no danger of that, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: No!—Why it is too late in life for you to marry, Sir Samuel—

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Hem!—Yes, Madam. No, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Indeed! So you—! Well! I should like to know your choice—Some staid body, I imagine.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Madam—Hem!—

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: But I would not have her too old, and disagreeable.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Hem! I can assure you, Madam—She—Hem!—She is a very beautiful young lady.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: You surprise me!—Oh! Then perhaps she is some low-born girl, who has more pride than understanding, and is willing to sacrifice her youth, and beauty, to the silly vanity of riding in a coach?

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Quite—Hem!—Quite the contrary, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p:
Then she must be poor, and must think
of marrying you for the sake of your riches, hoping you will die soon.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Madam—Hem! She is very rich.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Is it possible!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: And I should flatter myself would not expect me to die too soon.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Oh! But she will! Young women never marry old men, but with a wish to dance over their graves.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Hem!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Perhaps the poor girl may—may have made a faux pas.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Hem! Her virtue is unspotted, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: You amaze me! Young, rich, beautiful, and virtuous! What can her reason be for making choice of you? Why does not she rather marry some youth, whose rare qualities resemble her own?—Oh! I've found the secret at last! She's an idiot.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Hem! No, Madam—No—Hem!—I am afraid she has too much wit!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Nay then, Sir Samuel, you are the most fortunate gentleman I ever heard or read of!—But are you sure she is in love with you?

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Hem! N—Not very, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p:
No!—Oh ho! I have unriddled it at last! You have been bargaining for her with her father, or her mother, or—Ay, ay! The poor young lady's consent has never been asked!—And would you be so selfish as to seek your own single gratification, and be contented to see her condemned to misery, pining to death for the youth she loves, and justly detesting the
sight of you, as the wicked unfeeling author of her wretchedness?

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Hem! [Looking toward the door] Madam I—Hem!—I wish you a good evening.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: [Preventing his going] Another word, Sir Samuel. Have you ever talked to the young lady on the subject?

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Hem! I—Hem!—I have and—Hem! I have not.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: You never made a direct proposal?

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Hem! No, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: But why?

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: I, I—Hem!—I can't very well tell.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: But I can.—With much folly and depravity, there is still some virtue in you.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Madam! [Looking how to escape.]

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Though you could form so unjust a project, you never had the courage to insult the lady by an avowal of your guilt.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Hem! Guilt, Madam!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, guilt—However, Sir, she has perfectly understood your insinuations.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: She has infinite respect for filial duties. But, though she would beware of offending her parents, I know her to be equally determined never to entail misery on herself; nor to accept a husband whom she could neither esteem, admire, nor love!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Madam—I—Hem!—Your servant, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: [Between him and the door] Not till you first promise—

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: [Forgetting his fear] I'll promise any thing, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: That you will not render yourself more ridiculous, by persevering in so absurd, so unjust a pursuit.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: No, Madam! I'm quite ridiculous enough already!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Nay, more, that you will not seek some less friended, more enslaved, or more timid young creature, whom your misapplied wealth might command.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Whatever you please, Madam!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: But that you will rather apply your superfluous hoards to the protection of youthful innocence.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Suffer me but to depart, Madam, and I will bequeath my estates in perpetuity as you shall direct; I'll entail them on the Magdalen; or I'll advertise for marriageable men and maids, and you shall portion out my money among them! I'll—I'll do any thing, except marry, or go a courting!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Why then, Sir Samuel— [Kissing his hand] There—That be your reward.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Madam—Your humble servant.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Poor Sir Samuel! This is the first time he ever forgot his bow. [Enter the COUNT.] Well, Sir! have you effectually made your peace with my mamma?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I have done my endeavour, Madam—Would I were at peace with myself!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p:
And are you still, Sir, under the dominion of prejudice so weak? Do you still repent
of what you so long have deemed your condescension?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Far otherwise, Madam. There are beings so peculiarly favoured of heaven, and endowed with such high perfections, both of body and of mind, that they are superior to all the distinctions of men, among whom they walk angels upon earth! You are one of these! And my misery is, I never can deserve you!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: You may have stumbled, but this selfcondemnation shews it was but to rise with tenfold strength. Persevere, and we will be severed only by death.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: At length, my dear Count, Lady Peckham is pacified. To stoop to her ill-placed pride, to overlook her prejudice, and to petition as you did, was noble in you. I have seconded your efforts, have pledged myself for your honour, and guaranteed your veracity.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Then, Sir, you have struck a dagger to my heart! I have been guilty of falsehood! That very pride, and that exalted, or I fear extravagant, sense of honour, which should have preserved me from a stain so hateful, have dashed me down the precipice!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: You amaze me!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: 'Tis true, 'twas inadvertent; but rankling vanity, strengthened by a purer motive, the trembling alarms of love, induced me to persist; nay, a second time to aid deception.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: You did wrong—But which of us can say they never erred?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p:
Ay! Who will stand forth and affirm,
that, amid the rude whirl, the confused doubts, or the terrors of passion, they never once have been betrayed into your crime? For a crime I own it is; and with consequences so wide, so pernicious, and so fatal, that, when it shall be extirpated from the earth, that moment man will be perfect! But, in this poor world's present state, it is so far venial, that (painful, humiliating thought!) no—the noblest, the purest of us all, cannot strike his heart, and say—I never was a liar!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Frail as we are, and hourly as the arts of falsehood are practised upon us, to our detriment, and often to our ruin, those only are most free from guilt, who shake contagion soonest from them; and, by the next sublime effort of truth, scorning to shrink from shame, which is their due, in some sort turn the vice itself to virtue.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: But what have you said that—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Come, come! We must strike while the iron is hot! We must take my Lady while she is in the humour, since she must necessarily be a party in our deeds. And first I have agreed, as you know, Count, that my daughter's portion shall be 80,000l. The remainder will chiefly rest with you. What settlement do you intend to make? And on what estates?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: None, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: None!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I have no estates.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p:
Sir!—Why, what!—Zounds!—
After the enquiries I made, I cannot be so deceived! Are not you Count Connolly Villars?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I am, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: A colonel in the armies of the Most Christian King?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I am, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Recommended to me by Messieurs Devigny, the great merchants at Marseilles?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: The same, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Why, then, what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: When I first paid my addresses to this lady, I imagined my rank and family were a sufficient counterpoise to wealth.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Ha! Gold in one scale, honour in t'other?—Flimsy ware!—No, no—Kick the beam—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: But, ardent, violent, and eternal, as my love for your angelic daughter is, and must be, even the loss of her shall not tempt me, any longer, to practise the least imposition.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Well, but, 's blood! The steward! The family estates!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I have told you the truth, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: What's the matter, Lydia?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Poor Mr. Mac Dermot—!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: What of him?—Any harm?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: He has been in some fray, and is so bruised!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Bruised! Where is he?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Below, with a packet, which he wants to deliver to Sir Paul.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: To me?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Yes, Sir. Pray go to him.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: A packet for me! [Going] I shall never hear the last of this from my Lady!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Brother, go to my mamma, and endeavour to keep her in temper. [To the Count] Be not dejected! I know my father's affection for me, and do not yet despair. [Exit after Sir Paul.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Charming, generous girl!—This poor Mac Dermot!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: He is afraid of seeing you. He says you will never pardon him, for having taken the part of some man, whom you threatened to murder!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I? I threatened to murder no man!—Will you, Madam, be so kind as to tell him I am here; and that I insist on seeing him?

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: With pleasure. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Kingdoms should not tempt me to pass another day like this!

div3.stage: Enter MAC DERMOT, with his left Arm in a Sling.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: How now, Mac Dermot! Where have you been? What's the matter with you?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: No great matter, my Lord—Only a little bit of a joint here. [Pointing to his arm.]

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Alarmed] Broken?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: A double tooth or two—Not much, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Much!—How?—What have you been doing?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: [Pitifully] I hope your Lordship won't be angry! [Enraged] But the rascals sazed him neck and heels!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Seized who?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: [Passionately] He was as innocent as the babe unborn, my Lord, and he tould 'em so: [Rage] the dirty rapscallions!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Who are you talking of?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: [Pitifully] To be sure, he—he sent your Lordship a—a viry impartinent letter.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: How? [The Count's perplexities and passions are here effectually roused, and increase through the scene.]

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: There were three of them. Niver did your Lordship set your two good-looking eyes on such a pair of thieves!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: For heaven's sake, tell your story straight forward! What letter do you mean? Who?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: [With great emotion] I hope your Lordship will forget and forgive! It would have moved the bowels of your compassion, to have seen the ould gintleman!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Is it possible? What can he mean? What old gentleman?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: [Enraged] The dirty shaberoons took him by the throat—My viry blood boiled!—Upon my soul, my Lord, I could not bear it! I hope you will forgive me! By the merciful father, I could not bear it!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Tell me, this moment, who you mean!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: He came running back, out of breath, and asked for your Lordship. And so, my Lord, [Pleading] being a fillow-crater in distriss—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Came where?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p:
A couple of as ill-looking Tyburnturnpike bum-bailiffs as your Lordship could
wish! With a cowardly complotter at their back! It was he that came behind me with his shillalee, while I was hard at work with them both But the brave ould gentleman stepped in; ánd, by the Virgin's night-cap, but he gave him his dose!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Once more, tell me instantly, what old gentleman?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Considering his age, he is as active, and as brave a fillow, as ever handled a fist.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [Aside] He cannot surely mean my father! Mac Dermot, I entreat, I command you to tell me of whom you are talking.

sp.speaker: Mac. D.
sp.p: If your Lordship had but seen the noble ould soul, I'm sure you would have forgiven me.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: But what letter—?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Oh! The divle burn the letter! Now, my Lord, don't mention it! Pray don't remimber it, your Lordship! Pray don't! By my soul, now, my Lord, he is a fine ould fillow! Oh! How he laid about him!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Was it the person who came this afternoon?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: My Lord—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Fear nothing! Speak.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Why, then, my Lord—To be sure—it was he himsilf.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: And is he safe? Did you free him from them?

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Why, my Lord, I could not hilp it! [Emphatically] I could not hilp it! By the holy footstool, but I couldn't!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Mac Dermot! [Taking him by the hand.]

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: My Lord!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Well, well! A time will come—

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: My Lord!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Are you much hurt, Mac Dermot?—Here!—Hollo!— [Enter a Footman] Call a chair! Run for a surgeon and a physician! The best that can be procured.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: For me, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: For you, my noble fellow!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Spare yourself the labour, young man.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Go! Do as I order you; instantly. [Exit Footman.] Mac Dermot, you must be put to bed!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: To bed, my Lord!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: And lose some blood!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Faith, my Lord, that will be a little too much! I've lost quite blood enough already.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Pray! I request! I must have you do as I desire! I would not have any ill happen to you, for the world!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Oh! And the divle of ill or harm can happen to Mac Dermot, the while he has such an a ginerous prince royal of a master! Though I believe, the best thing that could happen to me just now, would be a good supper, and a hearty tiff of whisky punch.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Not for the Indies!

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Faith, my Lord, it was hard work; and has given me a very craving kind of a call.

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: The chair is waiting, Sir.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Go, my good fellow! Obey me but this once, and I'll never act the master to you more.

sp.speaker: Mac D.
sp.p: Well, well, my Lord. But I hope your Lordship won't quite kill me with kindness. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: [With the packet opened] So, Count, I find, after all your pretended raptures, you never wished to marry my daughter!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Why did not you retract like a man; and not make a paltry, false excuse of poverty?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir, I made no false excuse!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: How, Sir! Shall I not believe my eyes? Have I not bills here in my hand, drawn in your favour, for five hundred thousand crowns?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: In mine!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: In yours! Given me this moment by your own servant.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Impossible, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Impossible, is it? Why, look you, here are the bills: and, hollo! [Enter Footman] Go you, Sir, and desire Mr. Mac Dermot to come back.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Stir not for your life, on such an errand! He must not, shall not be disturbed.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Nay, my word, it seems, is not to be believed; nor perhaps the bills themselves! But, Sir, though you vaunt so highly of being a man of honour, the trick was beneath a man of honesty.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Here's a komakul kind of an obstroperous person, that says he must speak to the Count—You may come in, Mister.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p:
Ah! What, my friend the steward!
I am glad you are come! Never was so amazed in my life! Your master, here, has been telling me he has no estates!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: My master, Sir!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: The feelings of man cannot support this open shame! [Crossing to go.]

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Whither now, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Ay! Talk to him! I'm in a mist!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Suffer me to pass, Sir. [Crosses to the door] Speak the truth—Render me contemptible! Abhorrent! But make me not a witness of my own disgrace!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Stay, Sir!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I cannot.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Stay! Or dread a father's malediction!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: His Father! The plague! Hem!—Lydia!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Hush!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Father, indeed! Vhat he! So, so! Here's a wirago! Here's a chouse!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: My Lady—

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: I thought vhat vould be the upshot on't!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Madam. [Takes her aside for a moment in dumb shew.]

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p:
Spurred on by suppositions and conceits the most absurd, wholly intent upon yourself, contemning others, exacting respect you did not merit, refusing ceremony where 'twas due, protuberant with pride, yet poorly carping at and holding idiot warfare with the pride of others, forgetful of the dignity of reason, but with tenacious grasp clinging to the ludicrous
dignity of birth, the heir indeed and first born of Folly, ignorance itself has mocked and taunted at you!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Wery troo! Give him his own!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Zounds! My Lady!—I wish he would give you your own a little! Not but it's right enough!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: To be sure! I knows wery vell I am right

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Your father too has been avoided, nay disowned! Your father! Who for years has lived in indigence, that he might secretly supply your wants, support you in splendour, and preserve you from all the misery of which he made himself the willing victim!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir! You! Was it you? Oh! Ingratitude!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Your father was offensive to your sight! And what was it you despised? Why this poor garb! You wished no kindred with virtuous poverty! Had I appeared in all my former state, though knave or fool had been blazoned on my brow, yet, decked in the trappings of magnificence, I had received an open welcome. But, blest be my penury! Since it has been your punishment.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Sir, wrung as my heart is by remorse, and guilty as I know myself, for I have still increase of guilt, no words can mitigate my crimes. Yet, though I have erred, I feel I have something in me capable of good; and strong propensities to all the tender ties, the filial duties, and the severer virtues which I have seemed to want; a mind which, once convinced, has strength to shun and to subdue its master passion,
renounce its folly, and abhor its turpitude. Deep is my offence against you and nature! But let nature plead in my behalf. Here at your feet, repentant for my faults, I claim that pity which a father so good, and so affectionate, will not sure refuse.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Oh! No—For now you speak like the son of my heart, the image of my brightest hopes! You have stood the fiery trial, and are pure!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Vhy but hark you me, Mister—Vhy vhat! You are not a Count too, to be sure!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: No, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Vhy then—

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: If a title can flatter your Ladyship, mine is something higher.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: I am a Marquis.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: A Marquis! You! Vell! [Aside] For an outlandish Marquis!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: My Lady—!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Well but the bills? [Holding them out in his hand.]

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: They are mine.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Yours, Sir!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Remittances for some recovered arrears.—But where is my brave protector? My hero!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Safe, Sir! Every care is taken of the generous fellow.—Is the physician come?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Yes, yes. I have taken care of that. I have sent him my own physician. Hem!— [Aside] My cook!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: You know not half his worth!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Which shall not go unrewarded.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: No, by heaven!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: We have now the means; we no longer are oppressed and poor.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Yet are you not in present danger?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: No. Malice has spent its last effort. Our ambassador has just sent me the final decision of the judges: my sentence is reversed, my whole estates are restored, and the power of my persecutors is at an end.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Oh! Fortune! Oh! My Father!—And may I hope it?—My Lucy! May I—?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Yes! Hope every thing!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Mine!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Yours! Heart and soul!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: She is a brave wench!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Hold a blow, if you please! Vhat! Am I nobody?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Madam, to you a thousand excuses are due.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: To be sure they are!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I am conscious of my past ridicule, and will no more contend with your ladyship, for prejudices so false and weak.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: I knoo I vus right! I knoo you made yourself ridicolous! I told you so often enough!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Well said, my Lady!—But hark you, Miss Lydia— [Significantly] And, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: A moment's patience, Sir.—Count! How shall I tell him?—My son! Look at this charming, this virtuous young lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: [Aside] Zounds! What now?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
I am conscious of having treated her
with proud unkindness, at the very moment too, when I perceived she was sincerely my friend.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Your friend!—Look at her! Does not your heart throb? Feel you not sensations more tender?—Are you not all doubt, allhope, all fear, all perturbation?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir!—What!—Who?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Can you not imagine?—Look at her, I say!—Behold her agitation!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Mercy!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Open your arms, your heart, to receive her—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir! Madam! Who?

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Your sister!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: My sister!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: My dearest, best of brothers! [Runing into his arms.]

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: My friend! My Lydia!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Oh! How culpable have I been!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: [Aside] 'Sblood! Here's a pretty piece of business!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Vhat's that you say, Sir? Miss Liddy the Count's sister!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: 'Tis very true, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Troo! Vell, I purtest I'm quite in a quandary!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: [To Sir Paul.] And now, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: [Aside] Yes, 'tis my turn now!—Yes, Sir!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: While labouring to reclaim the follies of youth—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Yes, Sir!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: We ought not to forget the vices of age.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Hem! We'll talk of them after supper, Sir. [Looking round at Lady Peckham and the company.]

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p: Well, Sir, on condition—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Oh! Any condition you please, Sir!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: [Leading Lydia.] My dear Father!—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: My kind son! [Aside] Sly rascal!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: [To Sir Paul.] We shall want a house, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Hem! Ay, ay!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Somewhere in Mary-le-bone.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Very well!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: With a—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Zounds! [Aside to Lydia] Hush! Don't mention the back door!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Then we are all friends?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: To be sure—But, you may as well not tell Scapegrace!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Never fear.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Not a word of the new liveries!

sp.speaker: Lydia.
sp.p: Depend upon my honour.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: My sister and my friend! Can it be?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Would you not wish it thus?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Oh! Most ardently!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dor.
sp.p:
Chequered are the scenes of life. Pleasure and pain, joy and grief, austerity and laughter, intermingling, weave a motley web. Our prejudices are our punishments: they cling about us, warp our actions, distort our manners, render us the food of satire, the mockery of fools, and torture us, as wailing urchins are tormented to make sport for boys. Error and folly impede the progress of perfection.
Truth alone can make men wise and happy. Myself the sacrifice of falsehood and mistake, feebly have I striven to stem the torrent▪ and here my task, and here I hope my troubles end.

lg.l: THE curtain dropt, of course the author sends
Me to salute our gen'rous noble friends!
To me you listen, he politely says,
Whene'er I prattle, with a wish to praise.
For kindness so unceasing may you be
As happy, ev'ry soul, as your applause makes me!
But to my text—The theme to-night is Pride:
Much have we said—and much more have implied.
Our boldest strokes are feeble, nor can shew
The child of Pride with half his genuine glow;
Of Pride, which can such various forms assume;
Now rise an emperor, now sink a groom.
Mounted aloft, the wonder of his age,
With hackney coachmen furious war to wage;
Six swandown waistcoats swathe him into shape;
His legs all buckskin, and his coat all cape;
With manners, looks, and language such you'd swear
His tutor had been Piccadilly's Bear;
When most contemptible most hoping praise,
And only envious of the groom he pays;
Four dappled greys in front, behind three men;
Down Pall-Mall dashing, to dash up again;
Then only in his height and pomp of pride,
When Girl or Gambler's seated by his side;
Driving by day, dicing by night, his passion;
Such is the modern man of high-flown fashion!
Such are the scions sprung from Runny-Mead!
The richest soil, that bears the rankest weed!
Potatoe like, the sprouts are worthless found;
And all that's good of them is under ground.
Of Pride one single sketch in crayons more.
Behold her torch! Hark! Thunder shakes the door!
The carriage stops; the footmen make a lane;
The feathers stoop, and enter Lady Jane:
Perfect in how d'ye do, drop, bob, and bow.
(Curtseys, my friends, are out of fashion now)— [To the Galleries]
First to his Grace; next to the next of birth:
She none forgets—save genius, wit, and worth;
Whom if she mark, 'tis with a modish stare,
To ask who knows them? or, How came they there?
Now at the bank, in antichamber kept,
Where Pharaoh's host twelve tedious hours had slept,
She seats herself, like palpitating lover,
Eager the last night's losses to recover.
No sense of virtue, dignity, or shame:
Her greatest pride her knowledge of the game.
That pride most piqued, most mortified, to see
A Nabob's wife stake larger sums than she!
And now three anxious hours have slipt away:
Three hundreds have been lost, in piddling play.
No luck for her! Aloud fresh cards she calls:
Her passions rising as her pocket falls.
She punts: again she loses; and again!
Oaths quiver on her lip! She names the ten.
Stung to the soul, a desp'rate sett she makes;
Till even the winning banker deals and quakes.
Ghastly she pants, with horror in her eye,
To be the first the fatal card to spy.
The fatal card is turn'd, and ends the reign
Of Fashion, Folly, Pride, and Lady Jane!
Here too we end; oblig'd ourselves to own
Our pride is great—when we can please the town.
